output: Mr. President, first of all, I would like to congratulate Mr. Siebeb for the work done, as his report incorporates many of the concerns expressed on this occasion.

In this Chamber, concerning these crucial issues for the entire European Union—namely, water scarcity and drought—matters that have already ceased to be solely a problem for the countries of Southern Europe.

I am pleased that this project incorporates some of the reflections included in the opinion report, of which I was rapporteur in the Agriculture Committee, in favor of agricultural activity, highlighting, for example, the role that farmers play in the sustainable management of available resources.

It also includes a reference to drought and water scarcity as factors that exacerbate commodity prices, an aspect in which the current times also seem to me very important to highlight so that we bear in mind not only the environmental dimension of this problem, but also some of its most relevant economic consequences.

The Environment Committee also included the idea of creating a European drought observatory, an action likewise mentioned in the Agriculture Committee’s report and that I hope will one day be reflected in concrete actions.

The text to be put to a vote tomorrow incorporates, however, a proposal made by the Committee on Agriculture to study the implementation of an economic adaptation fund against drought, a fund that would benefit all economic sectors, including agriculture as well.

For my part, I would like to make it clear that I will continue to defend the establishment of this Fund, an idea that I will again propose to Parliament when, in the coming months, the Commission publishes the communication it has planned on adapting to climate change.

It seems to me that after the Solidarity Fund was established – originally created to mitigate losses caused by climatic disasters – it is time we consider an instrument that acts proactively and is intended to finance preventative measures to reduce the environmental and economic cost of those climatic catastrophes.

Mr. President, Commissioner, terrorism is a global phenomenon, and so is the activity of serious organized crime; therefore, measures must be proportionate and must be fought effectively.

But today I have taken careful note of the answers I have given to pertinent questions. It is true that guarantees must be demanded, it is true that it is a delicate matter, but it is no less certain that it is absolutely inexcusable to construct, to form a globalized and harmonized response.
For some, for whom terrorism feels a bit distant, individual guarantees are of greater concern.
I am concerned with both individual and collective matters, and it is absolutely necessary that we begin where we can.
If we are going to start with air transport, where companies already have that data, let's begin there.

Let us demand guarantees, let us see what the scope of application is, let us begin with international transport relationships and, mind you, we will have to continue with the domestic ones, because terrorists often do not come from outside, but from within.
Let the United States answer, and let others who experience it answer as well; and this is how we must frame it.
Mr. President, I would like to thank the Commission for presenting this proposal.
I believe it is a positive proposal and that it will help us reduce administrative burdens if necessary.
Now, as previous speakers have pointed out, this Parliament has the obligation to ground proposals that are very generous and very altruistic on the part of the Commission.

And the reality is that there is a national reality, one in which there are twenty-seven countries with different legal systems and vastly different languages, which necessitates that in each of these countries we adapt to the realities of the country, including the matter of languages.

Specifically, as Gossez pointed out just now and as previous speakers have indicated, it is important that the recognition of these national specializations does not lead to increased costs, that fees are uniform, and that governments ultimately bear this additional cost.
But there is a topic that also arises, and that is the topic of translations.
Specifically, within the European Union, we do not have a common language.

In the twenty-seven countries, very different languages are typically spoken among them; indeed, in some countries, such as that of the Commissioner, different languages are spoken, and we live with this.
And, from a legal standpoint, furthermore, we encounter the reality that legal documents are different.
Within the Legal Commission, for example, several amendments have been proposed regarding the authentication of documents, along with the authentication of the translation.
At this moment, the Committee on Legal Affairs is preparing a report on the recognition of authentic acts in different countries of the European Union, which should be complementary to this report.
Ultimately, I believe the Commission has done well in presenting this report.
The speaker has done a magnificent job, and I believe we have all strived to craft a legislative proposal that can be recognized throughout the Union, guaranteeing the
rights and starting from the foundations of the reality of a Union that is being built, which has different national legal systems and different levels of access to electronic communication.

Mr. President, a large majority of farmers and ranchers are awaiting decisions and agreements that the European Union’s Council of Ministers for Agriculture will adopt between today and tomorrow regarding this European Union audit.

from the CAP, because this is not a simple revision, but will bring about profound changes, such as the disappearance of many farms, if the cut proposed by the European Commission on direct payments goes ahead.

Modulation is the central point of this parliamentary report and could be one of the few elements of the Parliament's opinion to have some impact on the negotiations being conducted by the Union's Agriculture Ministers.
We have been opposing for years any increase in what we euphemistically call modulation, because if rural development policy does not have sufficient funds, it is
Not for lack of resources within the spending ceiling of the CAP, but for an absolute absence of political will to endow the Community budget with that necessary pillar development.
Do they want to liberalize the markets?
Certainly, do so, but with equal requirements and conditions for all producers, both within and outside the Union.

At this moment, the European Union is determining the future of many farmers and livestock breeders, and I would especially like to make a reference to vulnerable sectors such as sheep, beef, and tobacco, whose survival in many producing areas will depend on this assessment.

Some producers, such as those in the sheep farming sector, no longer request assistance, but simply want to be allowed to exit the market with dignity, because they have calculated that the only way to survive is to reduce production volumes.

Therefore, abandoning production is the only recourse we leave for many producers, whose space will undoubtedly be occupied by imports from third countries, because consumers will continue to consume and the world will continue to increase the number of consumers at a rapid pace.
Parliament should issue a considered opinion, and the Council should heed it.

I would like to express my gratitude from here to the President of the Agriculture Committee for the efforts made by Mr. Parris to ensure that Parliament is heard and has not been so overtly and conspicuously disregarded by the Council and the Commission as has been the case until now.
Mr. President, first and foremost, please add me to the congratulations extended by the honorable rapporteur, Mr. Capula Santos, for his magnificent work.

I believe that, at this stage of the debate, it is important to send a message of stability to our farmers.
European farmers need stability and solutions more than ever.
A sufficient transitional period is necessary, as well as maintaining specific measures that are required for sectors facing difficulty.
Madam Commissioner, the same solutions do not apply to all sectors.
It is important to remember that we have sectors experiencing genuine difficulties.
The Common Agricultural Policy does not have to be the problem, but the solution, and to that end, we need a strong first pillar.
We believe in and advocate for rural development, but we do not believe that the modulation proposed by the Commission is the solution.
It is not a matter of strengthening rural development at the expense of the first pillar.
We agree that the single payment scheme needs to be simplified, and that market instruments should be reviewed.
But that doesn’t mean dismantling them.
If we do this well, we will be laying the groundwork for a common agricultural policy beyond 2013; if not, we will be undermining the activity of many European farmers.
We are presented with a plan highly anticipated by the horticultural sector, not only due to the difficulties it faces, but also due to the concerning decline in consumption.
I believe we are facing a public health promotion plan. I believe it should be a European plan and I also advocate for full community funding.

I do not agree with the inclusion of parents in co-financing, because what will happen is the usual: parents who can contribute money will have their children consume fruits and vegetables in schools, while those who cannot will be left out of the program.
I believe it must be a community-funded plan to ensure its distribution is homogeneous.
Therefore, I also want to strongly emphasize that the focus should be on educational measures.

It is not merely about a student eating an apple, but about knowing what type of apple they are eating, understanding its nutritional properties, and comprehending the beneficial effects that the fruit has on their health and development.
Of course, these must be products with all quality guarantees, prioritizing, if possible, seasonal fruits and, whenever feasible, I advocate for the community origin of our fruits and vegetables.

I believe that the beneficial effects of this plan, which I applaud and for which I want to congratulate the Commissioner, we will notice them immediately, of course, for the present and future health of our children and their education.

food-related, but I also believe it is very important for the horticultural sector, a productive sector that constitutes a genuine European cultural heritage, as it allows us to enjoy a balanced, healthy, and varied diet.
I believe it is worthwhile to invest in and support this plan for the distribution of fruits and vegetables in our schools.
I believe the budget falls a bit short, because I reiterate my support for the full community funding of a plan as ambitious as this one.

I commend the speakers because with these two proposals we are taking a qualifying step towards a common immigration policy and entering into the promotion of legal immigration, a key pillar of the global approach we advocate.
The overarching framework of rights and the single residence and work permit for legal emigrants should be extended to the greatest number of workers.
Therefore, socialists are requesting that no category of workers be excluded.
The so-called Blue Card provides an opportunity for migrants to settle with their families and work in our countries.
It opens a unique door to twenty-seven labor markets.
However, through this door, highly qualified workers are not the only ones who should enter.
Therefore, Commissioner, we expect the Commission to present its proposals relating to the other occupational categories shortly.
Esteemed colleagues, we must combat the brain drain.
This blue card should not become a passport that encourages a drain of vital human resources from developing countries.
Therefore, from the Socialist Group, we want to ensure that for every qualified professional who comes to Europe, we fund the training of a new professional in their country of origin.
Finally, Europe must be an attractive destination not only for talent coming from outside the Union, but also for our own.
In 2007, nearly 300 highly qualified Europeans emigrated to work abroad.
Let us do everything possible to keep them within the European framework.

Mr. President, on behalf of the Socialist Group, I wish to express my Group’s strongest condemnation of the killings being perpetrated in this region of Somalia, invoking the name of God.
Few atrocities have been committed by someone who has not invoked the name of God or a religion.

Specifically, the manner in which this heinous murder was committed is now known: a 13-year-old girl who is raped and subsequently accused of adultery, and five men—if they can be called men—rush to stone her, preventing anyone from attempting to save her in a stadium occupied by a thousand people.

This, coupled with the acts of piracy that this year along the coast of Somalia have reached the level of nearly one hundred ships seized, constitutes a humanitarian situation that is absolutely unacceptable.
The international community cannot remain indifferent to this.
It cannot remain impassive in the face of cowardice, in the face of religious invocation to commit atrocities.
Therefore, we must restore order by supporting the legitimate government of Somalia in regaining control of the entire country and establishing a rule of law that respects human rights.
I believe that on few occasions has such a clear situation been presented to us, one that imposes obligations.
I do not believe that we can remain impassive here within this community of 500 million people and 27 countries, the most important in the world, without intervening in that situation.
I don't know how it will be possible, but, certainly, I believe it must be done and that intervention is needed rapidly.

I believe that the speaker and the previous speakers have highlighted the characteristics of this proposed Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council.
It concerns the recognition that armaments and ammunition are also within the internal market, albeit with a series of limitations.
These are not ordinary goods; they are not candies nor entertainment items, but rather objects that require precise control.
Certainly, there are limitations inherent in the Treaty itself, article 30 and article 296, which confer significant responsibilities on the States in the matter.
And the fact that we have a common market does not preclude States from being obligated to comply with safety regulations and having the right to enforce them when their own security is jeopardized.

I believe our model is not one of the free circulation of arms at any time, but rather a regulated market, controlled by the States and also, from now on, by the institutions of the European Union themselves.

We have a draft resolution on Nicaragua in which several aspects must be considered.
First, there are allegations of fraud, at least in two municipalities, Nicaragua and León, and this tarnished the outcome of the November 9th election.
On the other hand, we have a government that has been concerned with resolving some of the issues that erode human rights in Latin America.
Specifically, poverty, illiteracy, infant mortality, the distribution of potable water, and the lack of land tenure for indigenous peoples.
Therefore, when examining the case, we must distinctly differentiate the two aspects.

On the one hand, we must promote human rights and defend human rights in the traditional sense as political rights, and on the other, we must encourage the Nicaraguan Government, continuing in its role of assistance to the most vulnerable sectors of the country.
Of course, we must guarantee that the opposition can perform its function; we must oppose fraud, but we must defend the work of NGOs.
However, a balanced result must be achieved.

violations of fundamental rights, with regard to the criminal or non-criminal nature of the investigations and with regard to the number of municipalities in which the effect has produced some form of derogation.

In summary, we wish to condemn the alleged violations of fundamental political rights, but without going so far as to place the Government of Nicaragua in a difficult position to continue fulfilling its function of supporting the most vulnerable populations.
Mr. President, regarding the situation created in Nicaragua by attacks against some human rights defenders, against some fundamental freedoms, and against democracy.

It is unnecessary to recall here now Zoilamérica, nor Ernesto Cardenal, nor Carlos Mejía Godoy, nor Jarquín, nor Sergio Ramírez, nor so many other Nicaraguans who today feel betrayed in their hopes for a better Nicaragua.
In November 2006, Mr. Ortega requested and democratically obtained from the Nicaraguan people what he termed a new opportunity.
Today we already know what she wanted it for.
Since then, arbitrariness, nepotism, and corruption have become entrenched in the institutions of the Government, culminating in the electoral fraud of the November 9th elections.

Previously, very serious decisions had been adopted, such as the revocation of legal personality for certain opposition parties, threats and intimidation of civil society members, journalists, and media outlets.
President Ortega described the European Union governments as flies swarming over filth and characterized the external aid Nicaragua received as scraps.
He soon understood that there was not enough Venezuelan oil to dispense with that development aid.

As we prepare to enter a decisive phase in the negotiation of an association agreement between the European Union and Central America, the Government of Nicaragua should know that it will always find an ally and a friend in us.

But for us, the insistence on respect for human rights, freedom of expression, and democracy in general is a condition to which we do not renounce, because we believe that the people of Nicaragua especially benefit from it.
Until November 9th, municipal elections were held in Nicaragua.
As on previous occasions, that electoral process has been questioned from the perspective of democratic legitimacy, with accusations of fraud being made and incidents occurring.

There have been demonstrations and clashes between supporters of different political parties, resulting in numerous injuries and a deepening of the political crisis that this country has been experiencing.
Two political parties were unable to present themselves in the local elections, which is unacceptable because it restricts the fundamental right of all citizens to political participation.

On the other hand, we have received direct testimony from representatives of human rights organizations who have informed us about the existence of questioning of the judicial system by civil society.

regarding the existence of administrative repression mechanisms that have brought as many as 17 organizations of social movements before the courts, concerning the persecution of independent journalists and even the European Commission delegation.

For all these reasons, we wish to raise our voices and make an appeal, firstly, to political parties to condemn the acts of violence perpetrated by their supporters, and secondly, to the Government itself to reopen spaces for participation.

democracy and human rights, all without prejudice to our continued provision of assistance from Europe for the development and well-being of the Nicaraguan people, whom we desire to have the best possible future.

However, the sector is deeply concerned because the European Parliament does not understand the impact that this Regulation may have on the future.
It is the case that there are assessments of its potential impact which indicate that, due to the limited future availability of plant protection products, it will be very difficult
control of pests and diseases affecting the cultivation of a wide range of foods, specifically all Mediterranean products, as well as the cultivation of ornamental plants and cut flowers.
I am not fully aware that the agreement adopted in the three-way dialogue has been the result of a vigorous negotiation, and I cannot but acknowledge the work done by the rapporteurs.

However, it must be considered that the temporal definition of endocrine disruptors will lead to the disappearance of a large number of active substances, particularly insecticides, of key importance to agriculture.

Producers must have a sufficient quantity of active substances available to effectively and safely combat any plant disease or pest, bearing in mind that the danger often lies not in the product itself, but in its misuse.
For all these reasons, the Spanish delegation of the PPE-DEI Group supports the proposals requesting an impact assessment and will vote in favor of the amendments.
from Mr. Stardy, which I myself have signed, relating to endocrine disruptors and those that favor the availability of plant protection products in cases of emergency.

Furthermore, if this Regulation is adopted as per the reached agreement, the effects will be a reduction in food production and an increase in prices, leading us to import those very foods that we are not producing, processed with products that we are prohibiting.

Mr. President, Mr. Capato, your report is a report brimming with good will. The most evident proof of this is that it did not warrant any amendments during its consideration by the Committee on Civil Liberties.
Were you yourself the one who introduced eighteen amendments to your own report?
And it is those amendments that have introduced a greater degree of radicalism—let’s say that in general terms—which raise very serious doubts for me.
I would structure the amendments you have proposed—amendments you have posed to yourself, I insist—into four distinct stages, within a report that initially received the support of all groups.
Some impossibilities, their aunts and uncles, and some things that are impossible.

For example, Mr. Capet, you are requesting things for which there is no legal basis as yet. For example, until the Treaty of Lisbon enters into force, it will be impossible to harmonize the regulations of different committees.
Something very similar has just been stated by Commissioner Wallström. Or you request, for example, that we declare 2009 the year of transparency. We are late, there is no longer any time.
Therefore, you are requesting things that are impossible.
Furthermore, he requests some others that are inadvisable.
For example, you request that there be transparency in the meetings of political groups.
I don’t believe it.
Because privacy is necessary, privacy is a political good.
If I wish to dissent from my party, to maintain an opposition, I want to do so privately, and that is not a lack of transparency.
Transparency should be demanded of public bodies, but not within political parties, where debates must be guaranteed in privacy.
Therefore, I cannot continue with him/her/it in that regard.
There are some other assessments you make, Mr. Capato, that are uncertain.
For example, you say that 90% of legislative activity is due to committee work.
That is a reckless exaggeration, Mr. Capato.
And furthermore, climatology inherently carries norms of transparency within itself.

If what we are going to do now is create more mechanisms, more bureaucracy, more controls, we will be acting contrary to what we aim to achieve, which is transparency—something closely linked to simplicity.
And finally, before the President calls me to order, because I am already consuming my time, there are some things that are unnecessary.
For example, I understand that it is very appealing and very attractive to public opinion to say transparency in the activity of the deputies, that it be known that they attend the Plenary Sessions.
That much is known, Mr. Capato.
What is submitted to committees is already known to be documented in minutes, which are accessible acts for all citizens.
or the diets that charge, well, you know, Mr. Capato.
That is to say, it is perfectly possible for a citizen to have access to that information.

Therefore, I understand that it is very appealing to public opinion and that defending transparency is highly commendable. However, I want you to know that transparency is about showing things as they are, and when one contributes to obscuring the truth, Mr. Caputo, then we are not contributing to transparency.
Thank you for your generosity, Mr. President.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, as we have seen recently, the textile sector is experiencing a significant crisis that has resulted in numerous company closures, relocations, and unemployment—events that are concentrated precisely in regions specializing in this activity.

Mr. President, given this current economic situation of crisis, the European Commission should act swiftly alongside the Member States to alleviate the socioeconomic effects of this restructuring, particularly dramatic for the affected territories and families.

I believe it is necessary to provide assistance to workers in the textile and garment sector with social measures, with plans for companies that are undergoing restructuring and are currently in serious difficulties.
It would be desirable to allocate a substantial portion of the Globalization Adjustment Fund to the restructuring and reskilling of the textile sector.
particularly concerning small and medium-sized enterprises, which predominantly comprise the sector in the European Union and are disproportionately affected by market liberalization.
On the other hand, it is necessary to reinstate the system of control over imports originating from abroad and, particularly, due to their volume, originating from China.
It is not about promoting trade barriers at all.

It is a matter of offsetting the negative effects of such a significant transformation, and we must not forget that the European Union is the world’s second-largest exporter of textile and apparel products.

This necessitates ensuring the best possible access conditions to third-country markets, essential for the future of the textile and garment industry based in the European Union and, particularly, for SMEs.
All of this, of course, ensuring fair competition based on the promotion of environmental and social standards in these countries.

In this regard, the publication of accurate information to the consumer, for example, with the Medium Labeling Regulation, which, to our knowledge, has not been implemented, would be highly beneficial, as
This, among other things, would entail subjecting imported products to the same safety and consumer protection requirements as those manufactured within the European Union.

Mr. President, within the EU there are various cases of languages belonging to historical European peoples that, because they are not constituted as states, are not permitted to be used in the debates of this Parliament, and this is a democratic and representative deficit.

One such case is that of the Basque language, *euskera*, which is not a minority language but an official one, at least in the southern part of the Basque Country, which administratively falls within the Spanish State.

But the same does not occur, and please do not take this personally, Commissioner with the Basque Country of the North, affiliated with the French State, whose president, before the Assembly of the United Nations, asserts that denying respect to national identities and languages fuels humiliation, and that without such respect there will be no peace in the world.
And then, neither Basque, nor Corsican, Breton, nor Occitan receive the slightest official consideration, nor do they benefit from support to respect or promote their use.

Therefore, I request that the Delhi Agency for Fundamental Rights work to ensure that within the Member States, the rights of no European people to their mother tongue are violated, nor are their inhabitants discriminated against, and that all of them are considered official within their respective territories.
Thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for your assistance, on behalf of all European languages.

Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank our rapporteur, Claudio Fava, for his considerable work in reaching a common position with the Council, which includes many improvements proposed by our Parliament.
With this Directive, we once again demonstrate our commitment to building a common migration policy based on a holistic approach.
The aim of this Directive is clear: to combat trafficking, to punish unscrupulous employers, and to protect exploited immigrants who have no social protection whatsoever.

We want the unjust, meager wages paid to immigrants to disappear, and furthermore, we want average salaries to be dispersed, particularly in sectors such as construction, agriculture, domestic service, or hospitality.
These measures require considerable courage and political will, as there are many vested interests and a significant amount of money circulating within the shadow economy.
Precisely in times of difficulty, it is more important than ever to manage migratory flows intelligently, with generosity but with responsibility.
It would be easy to fall into the temptation of not trying to curtail the shadow economy.
We cannot turn a blind eye and leave approximately eight million undocumented immigrants in a state of defenselessness, facing working conditions bordering on slavery.

Honorable members, if we want this Directive to be effective, rigorous inspections and economic, and even criminal, sanctions in the most aggravated cases are necessary—measures that will have a deterrent effect on businesses.
We will thus reduce the pool of undeclared economic activity and curtail the incentive for migration generated by the possibility of working irregularly.
It must be made clear that the only option for working in Europe is the legal route.

Therefore, we want to continue with the global approach and we ask the Commission, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Barrot, to present as soon as possible the new Blue Cards, quotation marks, for the other occupational categories.
Mrs. Ferrero Waldner, Mr. Solana, I would first like to thank the three rapporteurs for their work, and, as shadow rapporteur for the report on CFSP, I will address the issue of CFSP.

Regarding this report specifically, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr. Sarkozy Bolski on the outcome of his work and for the collaboration he has offered to the other groups, resulting in a consensus-based result.

Just as this Parliament has repeatedly called for the European Union to be equipped with the necessary instruments to speak with a single voice in the world, so too does this Chamber demonstrate its cohesion in evaluating and promoting major priorities in foreign policy and common security.

Our Group, the Socialist Group, has pursued a dual direction: on the one hand, to introduce or reinforce major issues that are key for us, transversally across all foreign policy, such as the fight against climate change, the promotion of the

peace across the entire planet or a bet on human development. On the other hand, to propose elements of rebalancing between the geographical priorities of the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) with respect to how they originally appeared in the text, if they appeared at all, or to introduce them as a new element if they were absent.

In this manner, we have advocated, for example, for a greater clarification of the relationships between the institutional and cooperation frameworks involved in the eastern dimension, recently defined.

We have advocated for greater diversification and increased relevance in our relations with Africa, a continent of which we often only remember when wars of particular virulence occur, and often not even then.

Regarding Latin America, we have ensured that the current processes of negotiating association agreements are reflected, the first of a bi-regional nature that the European Union will conclude throughout its history.

Regarding the Mediterranean, we have opposed a reductionist approach that speaks only of security, to instead include the rich political, economic, and sociocultural heritage contained within the Barcelona process.

Regarding amendments for the plenary session, our Group has not submitted any, believing that doing so would somehow reinforce the balance achieved through commitments, and therefore we will oppose the majority of the amendments in order not to weaken the agreement reached in the Foreign Affairs Committee.
Mr. President, the Venezuelan referendum has concluded with a victory for the "yes" vote, gracefully acknowledged by the democratic opposition.

It is no less true that equality of opportunity has not existed in the campaign and that the incumbent administration has enjoyed the overwhelming support of the entire state apparatus, while the opposition has suffered constant harassment and coercion.
Even under those conditions, the country has been practically divided into two halves, and it will be very difficult to build the future with only one of them.
The European Union must promote dialogue, inclusion, and consensus among Venezuelan political and social actors for the good of the country.
It is not through visceral attitudes, disparagement, or insults that we will help Venezuela find its democratic, pluralistic, and free path.

In that regard, we criticize the decision by the Venezuelan government to expel a Spanish Member of the European Parliament and, more importantly, the manner in which that expulsion was carried out, but we appeal to this Parliament to avoid

that our representatives make statements during their visits to third countries that violate local legislation, and even less so that they insult a head of state, however criticizable that head of state may be.
With these attitudes, we are jeopardizing future missions of the European Parliament to other countries.
Mr. President, I have just returned from Venezuela, where I was invited by its electoral authority as a member of an international electoral observation group for the referendum held on the 15th.

The European members of that group have submitted a report to the National Electoral Council, offering an overall positive assessment of the process regarding its organization, transparency, participation, free and secret exercise of the right to vote, and security in all its phases.

Regarding the statements made by Deputy Herrero to a Venezuelan television station, I note that they sought to delegitimize the ongoing electoral process, leveled serious accusations against democratic institutions in that country, and bordered on interference in the internal politics of a sovereign nation.
Our Parliament should not foment any type of confrontation with the democratic institutions of Venezuela.
Conversely, it would be incumbent upon the honorable member of parliament to provide explanations to this Chamber regarding an action that impacts us all.
Finally, the Budget Committee opines that a clear delimitation of each budgetary instrument is of the utmost importance.

Therefore, the most realistic option appears to be the creation of a new instrument for actions distinct from public development assistance for countries falling within the scope of application of that Regulation.
From a budgetary perspective, the proposed funding from the Development Commission appears unsuitable, as that money does not exist.
Do not count those lines with a credit amount assigned on a multi-year basis. There is a credit for 2009, but no further credits beyond that.
In any case, given that the financing of this new cooperation instrument must be compatible with the 2007 financial framework, it is advisable
It is necessary to remember the importance of the mid-term review of the financial framework, which should allow for an adjustment of the maximum limits of the various budget lines.
Madam President, at this late hour on Monday, the Commission likely has other matters that concern it more than this report.
Ultimately, what we are doing is nothing more than responding to a report from the Commission, a report on the implementation of Regulation 1206 of the
Council Decision of 28 May 2001 on cooperation between the judicial authorities of Member States in the taking of evidence in civil or commercial matters.
We are in a decidedly non-community area, an intergovernmental sphere in which, from the Council, through Regulation, efforts have been made to encourage cooperation among those judicial bodies.
But in doing so, I believe there is a certain lack of rigor on the part of the European Union.

That is to say, certain measures have been planned, for example, the publication of practical guides, the use of electronic media, etc., but I acknowledge that action on the part of the Commission is quite difficult.

I do not know what the Commission has achieved or intends to achieve, but it seems quite difficult to achieve it given the enormous difficulty that this form of intergovernmental cooperation presents.

We are requesting this from judicial authorities, who are collaborating with one another. We are talking about twenty-seven countries, judicial authorities managing twenty-two different languages, with very distinct legal systems, and we are attempting to achieve results.
The Commission has observed that the results are not good, that there is a significant delay in these cooperation mechanisms, and, of course, that we do not have the resources to do so.
Ideally, one would have material resources.
For example, what could the Commission do to equip judicial bodies, particularly those at a lower level, with technological elements such as a videoconferencing system?
Videoconferencing may be a utopia in many small courts across the European Union, but it appears to be the only way to accomplish it.
I believe that the European Union should rely on existing institutions, specifically the European judicial network.
We should strengthen this institution so that judges themselves, through their cooperation systems, could develop this type of communication.
On the other hand, any form of judicial training is fundamental.
This is something the Commission also cannot do on its own.
But the Commission can indeed stimulate the development of this type of training courses in Community Law and in the knowledge of the different legal systems.
Then there is a significant difficulty, which is the problem of languages, that is, how can one communicate, let's say a Spanish judge with a Finnish judge, with two such different languages.
It cannot be expected that judges, in addition to having to manage their own law, which is already complex in itself, be obligated to have knowledge for that type of
What practical steps can we take to facilitate the task of interpretation and translation for judges?
translation, that is, what could we do to help them do it.
In presenting this report, I express no rigor or harshness toward the Commission.
I believe the work is quite difficult.
What I would like to know, leveraging what we have here, for a commissioner interested in this topic, what does the Commission think can be done to provide greater

Strictly adhering to this 2001 Regulation, which is somewhat imprecise, somewhat voluntaristic, and I’m not sure if, from a practical standpoint, it can have any consequences or if it can be used to achieve progress.
Mr. President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, I am very pleased to be able to conclude this legislative term with the final approval of the last of the maritime packages.

However, I recall that when I arrived at the European Parliament in 1999, we experienced a major maritime accident, the Erika oil spill near the French coast, which lent its name to an initial block of legislative proposals aimed at addressing and preventing accidents.

We believed we had already banished the danger, but shortly thereafter the coasts of Galicia were devastated by the slick resulting from another, even greater accident than the first, that of the ship.

Since then, within the Transport Committee, we have worked on successive legislative packages, attempting to overcome the excessive resistance encountered from shipowners, oil companies, classification societies, and also from certain Member States who rejected our proposals for considering them too demanding.

Over these ten years, we have approved various directives and regulations, some of which we have had to revise because, due to cuts initiated by the Council, they proved ineffective in their initial formulation.

We approve the regulations for the introduction of double-hulled ships, the European Fund for Large-Scale Oil Catastrophes, safe havens, and now we review and approve the liability of passenger carriers by sea, the investigation of the

maritime accidents, the Community system for the tracking and information of maritime traffic, control by the port State authority, and finally, the Regulations and Directive concerning ship inspection and certification organizations.
And all of this is good and desirable to come into effect and be applied by all Member States in the shortest possible time.
Therefore, I feel satisfied.
But the legislative term ends, I leave Parliament with the regret of not having managed to establish as mandatory the introduction of control systems that exist.
They are patented to determine when and how many residues of centinelas and fuel tanks have been illegally discharged into the sea by a specific vessel.
That is to say, a sort of black boxes or tachometers that can be inspected by maritime authorities each time a vessel arrives at port.

I believe we owe the marine environment greater attention and stricter procedures to address the significant pollution we generate, and that if we fail to do so, it will affect our food chain and our lives, making us pay a high price.
I trust that another ten years will not pass before we can more effectively and efficiently control illegal marine discharges.
Mr. President, the revision of the Eurovignette Directive is a matter of great importance that concerns and worries us all, particularly peripheral countries, who feel like victims of this proposal.
The European Commission has decided to address the internalization of the external costs of road transport by assigning three new costs: air pollution, noise pollution, and congestion.

While the principles inspiring the “user pays” and “polluter pays” proposal are reasonable, the proposed solution itself is not, as it will be discriminatory toward a sector that has been suffering the disastrous effects of the economic crisis for months.
Demonizing road freight transport, even if it wasn't the objective, has proven to be the outcome.

This proposal, ladies and gentlemen, is untimely and, far from achieving the expected objectives of sustainable transport, would be a death sentence for a large number of small and medium-sized European enterprises that employ thousands of people.

There are individuals within the European Union who contribute daily to the distribution of goods, ensuring that products reach their final consumer—a consumer who will see their products become more expensive due to the implementation of these tariffs.
Honorable members, we need a competitive, sustainable, and environmentally friendly transportation system, without overlooking the road, because currently it is the only way to reach everywhere.
Modal shift remains a dream, far from becoming a reality.
Trans-European networks, maritime highways, and cross-border connections remain, in some cases, projects and not realities.
Esteemed colleagues, when the Titanic of the global economy is sinking, it is not possible to ask the orchestra to continue playing, let alone for entertainment.

Mr. President, the European Commission, on 15 July 2008, adopted a communication addressed to the Council and the Parliament, recommending the establishment of a strategic partnership between the European Union and Mexico.
For its part, the European External Action Service, on October 13th, recognized Mexico as a strategic partner, awaiting the Parliament’s opinion on the matter.
Let us recall that already during the seventh meeting of the European Union-Mexico Joint Parliamentary Commission, held at the end of October last year, we stated that a
A strategic partnership between Mexico and the European Union represents a necessary impetus to strengthen and develop the true potential of our bilateral relations.
We noted the opportune timing of relations between both parties and the positive assessment of the current global agreement.

We insist on the need for our respective executives to strengthen collaboration in political, economic, and maximum cooperation matters in the face of the new challenges of all kinds stemming from the financial and economic crisis shaking our continents.

With the great country that is Mexico, we share values and objectives such as the development of democratic forms of government, a commitment to gender equity, the consolidation of the rule of law, equitable and sustainable development, and the respect for human rights.

We advocate for strengthening cooperation in the fight against organized crime, terrorism, and drug trafficking, based on the principles of shared responsibility and strict adherence to international law.
Consequently, we will support the proposal of recommendations regarding the Strategic Association European Union Mexico, which will be submitted to Parliament this morning.
Mr. President, regarding the report on microcredit, I would like to congratulate all the speakers because they have done a great job.
The Commission’s initiative has undoubtedly improved.
I understand that the recommendations established here will allow us to form the foundation for developing a genuine framework within the European Union for the microcredit sector, a sector
that has been successful in many developing countries, even in some European ones, both as a mechanism of economic activity and as an instrument for improving social inclusion and job creation.

But it hadn't been transferred to the sector or the community context, and I believe that presents an opportunity to do so, particularly starting from the economic and financial context in which we find ourselves.
It is therefore essential to reinforce the initiatives advanced here, but further steps must be taken.
It is necessary to increase the available funds for this microcredit support structure.
It is necessary to facilitate availability for individuals and companies that lack access to loans, and in that sense, Madam President, I would like to highlight the example of the
the European guarantee for microcredit loans as an instrument that can facilitate that access and which has been included in the report.
And I conclude that, without a doubt, this will lay the groundwork for us to create a harmonious framework within the European context that promotes the microcredit sector.

Madam President, taking advantage of the fact that we are discussing the budget, I believe we must prepare ourselves for the negotiation next year of the continuation of subsidies for coal, an essential indigenous energy source.
And I say this with due advance, because inappropriately, some senior official, misleading public opinion, allowed themselves to express an opposing view, leaking it to an economic publication.
None of that.
It will be necessary to continue supporting my country’s coal after 2012, and I want that noted in the minutes.
Gentlemen, officials, limit yourselves to complying with the current plan and, subsequently, from 2012 onwards, with the instrument we begin to negotiate with the sector next year.
Mr. President, Commissioner, this question, as Mr. Böckland has explained, is very timely, given the diplomatic conference on the Ship Recycling Convention that will be held in May.
Therefore, I wish to congratulate Mr. Blokhan not only on the question, but also on the resolution he has prepared.

Mr. President, in the Popular Party, we support the fight against bad practices and methods employed in ship dismantling, and therefore, we support Mr. Brokland’s proposed resolution; however, there are some points that concern us.

The first is section 3, which he has also pointed out, stating that ships, in their entirety, must be considered hazardous waste and, as a consequence, must fall within the scope of the Basel Convention.

We have presented an amendment on this section because there are different interpretations both within and outside the European Union, and we believe that the Basel Convention must be taken into account and should not contradict it, but the future international agreement on ship recycling should define the details of its application.
The draft resolution also requests, in point 14, a financing mechanism based on mandatory contributions from the maritime transport sector.

It seems to us rather premature to discuss mandatory contributions at this time, when it has not yet been decided within the IMO what system will be adopted for this financing, and it appears to me that the European Commission also does not have a clear answer regarding this matter.
Finally, in point 15, the Commission is urged to clearly establish that the State with jurisdiction over waste is the responsible State.
Therefore, we believe it is the Commission's prerogative to decide this, which should also be determined in an international agreement.

The important thing is to ensure consistency regarding the future Ship Recycling Convention and the Basel Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and Their Disposal, and all of this taking into account not only the Basel Convention but all existing legislation.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, colleagues, the first thing I would like to do is congratulate the rapporteur, with whom we share a great deal of common ground regarding this program, and congratulate us all, because in times of economic crisis it is essential to maintain a program like this, with clear positive social effects.

Although we are facing a consultation procedure from the European Parliament, we must send a clear political signal that, in these times of economic uncertainty, from Brussels and Strasbourg, we are not exclusively concerned.

We are not only concerned about the recovery of the financial system, but we are fully aware that social policies, particularly those that support those most in need, the poorest citizens of the European Union, must grow.

This food distribution program must continue to be considered part of the common agricultural policy; on this point, we concur with the Commission, not only because European agriculture has a distinct social character, but because it is a functioning instrument, because it is needed now more than ever, and because it must continue to function.

From the Socialist Group, as is the case with the rapporteur, we oppose this program being confidential between the European Union and the Member States, as this would represent a discrimination between States according to their wealth, with the possibility that the program could not be implemented in the most disadvantaged countries.

It is incomprehensible that now, when it is needed most, the Commission wishes to economize on community funds in the most social aspect of the CAP, especially considering that there are budgetary surpluses in the agricultural budget every year.
Full community funding is essential for us.
We need to ensure that this program reaches all countries and, above all, those most in need.
Therefore, 43 million potential beneficiaries of this program are demanding greater effort from us, and in no case, a reduction in budgetary expenditure.
Austerity, yes, but not with the most vulnerable.
It is precisely to ensure that it reaches the citizen of all Member States that the program must cover the entire journey of the distributed food.

Therefore, from the Socialist Group, for which I am responsible for the report, we have presented an amendment so that all expenses arising from distribution, including those of transport, storage, and administrative costs, are covered by Community funds.
We also agree with the speaker that food should preferably be community-sourced and of high quality.
It is a position consistent with that maintained by this Parliament in other similar programs that we recently discussed in this Chamber, such as the plan for distributing fruit in schools.
That's all, and many thanks.
We hope that the Commission will consider the position of this Parliament when it votes and, above all, that the European Union's plan is implemented as soon as possible.
The Arctic region is one of the most fragile regions of our planet.
The consequences of an unrestricted exploitation of its natural resources would be catastrophic not only for the immediate environment and for the indigenous population, but for the world as a whole.

The melting of vast areas has brought these risks to the forefront, making a new, globally-reaching regulation necessary to protect the Arctic, similar to the one already in place for the Antarctic, even considering the differences that have been highlighted in the debate.

An international treaty between all parties involved, including, without doubt, the European Union, is necessary to protect its unique environment, ensure the fully sustainable nature of all types of human activities, and multilaterally regulate navigation through the new maritime routes that are becoming accessible.
The Arctic Council, throughout its years of existence, has been a model of cooperation in managing common problems.

In these moments of difficulties and uncertainty, we must elevate that spirit and that accord to a higher level to prevent states in the region or other international actors from becoming embroiled in geopolitical conflicts, forgetting what should be the common objective: the preservation of a vast shared heritage.
Mr. President, unlike the two speakers who have just preceded me, I agree with most of the participants.
This is a good directive, an excellent directive aimed at protecting interpreters.
When discussing the need to find a more intelligent business model, what is actually being discussed is the elimination of intellectual property.
Business can only be conducted if there is an established right.
We already have an established right at the national level.
The Commission, under the direction of Mr. McCreevy, has adopted a bold initiative, a positive initiative, and I believe the House should approve the agreement we have
We have achieved this within the scope of the Committee on Legal Affairs thanks to the work of the rapporteur, Mr. Crowley, and the various shadow rapporteurs, such as Ms. McGuill and Mr. Tuppence.
I believe it is a magnificent Directive, a Directive that will strengthen the creation of intellectual property.
And, moreover, this Directive includes several recommendations with respect to the continuation of work.

I believe that this Chamber's approval of that report and I hope that the Council aligns with the lines of the Council, the Commission, and the Parliament will serve to ensure that in the next legislature the

May the Commission continue along this path, make proposals to the Parliament, and advance in the area of intellectual property protection, which is essential for the development of our European Union as a great institution based on a common culture.

Mr. President, the information you provide me is correct, but the impression we, the European parliamentarians and, ultimately, European citizens, have is that there is a very dangerous gap in Community law.
At this moment, as fiscal demands are increasingly reinforced in each of the Member States, mobility is almost impossible.
And when we ask the Commission the reason for the pragmatic approach, it is because the Commission never finds support in the Council.

We need a sort of vicious circle whereby the Commission refers us to the Council and the Council refers us to the Commission; however, in the meantime, the reality is that citizens living in this Europe we want to build do not have the possibility of living in different countries or establishing relationships as a result of the heavy fiscal burden that a lack of fiscal harmonization can entail.
fiscal Can the Council do anything to help us break this vicious cycle?
Madam President, for once I am glad that the usual speaker is not present, that Mr. Tajani has come, because Mr. Tajani has the advantage of having been a Member of the European Parliament.
And, as a Member of the European Parliament, I know that you have experienced the frustration that Members of the European Parliament have regarding the implementation of Community law.

Now, in Parliament we tend to interfere with the Commission, and I believe we are asking the Commission an impossible task, because all Community law and all the application of Community law is based on indirect application.

That is to say, the Commission has, aside from a few officials at headquarters, where it receives some complaints and has limited avenues for action, but, at this time, there is also a trend toward restricting budgetary powers, meaning the Commission will not have the possibility to do so.
All Community law, all application of Community law, is based on the action of national authorities, national parliaments, national judges, national officials.
And here, in this aspect, I do not believe we can demand too much of the Commission.
What we need to do is assist the Commission, and I believe that there are some points in Mrs. Frazzoni’s report that may be useful in achieving this application.
I refer to those relating to the correlation of directives, the collaboration of national parliaments, and the actions of national courts.
Mr. President, two years ago, during a mission led by my colleague, my group partner here present, Marianne, I had the opportunity to visit.
Sierra Leone and of being present in this court and of being aware of the immense work that this court was undertaking, not only for Sierra Leone, but for all of humanity.
The Special Tribunal for Sierra Leone, as has already been stated here, has certainly established a precedent.

A precedent, because, as the Resolution clearly indicates, it is the first international tribunal funded by voluntary contributions, the first tribunal established in the country where the alleged crimes occurred, and also the first tribunal, as has already been noted, in which a former prime minister has been tried.

For all these reasons, not only because it sets a precedent, but because it serves as a reference for other tribunals that have been established in its wake, such as Rwanda, former Yugoslavia, Cambodia, or Lebanon, we consider it essential that this Resolution be approved, on which we have been working jointly with the Tribunal for several months.
Two years ago, we approved a resolution to support its funding. Two years ago, the Tribunal was going through a difficult period in which it was running out of
There was no funding, and there was insufficient support. We must also acknowledge the European Commission’s support, let’s say, financial support for this Tribunal.

Now, above all, we request two things: first, that those convicted individuals serve their sentences; at stake is not merely the functioning of the Tribunal, which ends next year, but the legacy this Tribunal will leave behind. Secondly, obviously, all of this must be accompanied by increased funding.
Ultimately, the Special Court for Sierra Leone is an example and a reference for all of us and for all the courts that have prosecuted war crimes.

It is an example and a reference, and a lesson that the second poorest country on this planet is giving us, in which, upon entering the courtroom, we saw a motto written that read: without justice, there is no peace.
And precisely for that reason, we have a moral obligation, not only as Europeans but as human beings, to ensure that the legacy of this Tribunal remains permanent in history.

Mr. President, with the utmost brevity, which I trust my Lords and Ladies will appreciate at this hour, Mr. Vice-Chair of the Committee, many thanks, Mr. President of the Commission, because you have demonstrated, as you did in the third package of measures,

Maritime, whose impetus, whose political standing, has been capable of driving an agreement near the Council and making possible that Parliament, Council, and Commission could reach agreement at this juncture and in these final days, where the legislature concludes.
I believe we need to congratulate ourselves.
I undoubtedly appreciate the close collaboration demonstrated by the speakers, both in the JURI Committee and in the Environment Committee.

I acknowledge and reiterate the work and collaboration of the rapporteurs working behind the scenes, and ultimately, I believe that if we adopt an agreement at first reading tomorrow on such an important regulation, it will undoubtedly complete the work of the

The third maritime package represents a success for this Parliament and for the European Union across its three institutions and justifies, once again, the codecision procedure, which is useful and allows for constructive dialogue in favor of all citizens of the European Union.
Mr. President, I am a minute short before I want to respond to the Commissioner, who knows of my friendship and affection for her, and indeed, of my friendship and affection for Mr. Orbán.
But the police commissioner has not uttered a single word about the Ombudsman's recommendation.

That is to say, the Ombudsman, who is familiar with all the arguments that the Commissioner has presented to us, has made a precise recommendation that the Commission appears to be ignoring in its entirety.

I don’t even want Mrs. Cunha to respond to me, because evidently she is not the one who has the data, but all the data she has given me is consistent with what we knew and with what the Ombudsman also knows, and he doesn’t tell us if, indeed

Despite all of that, and as the Ombudsman, who is aware of this, recommends that the regulation be changed, he does not tell us whether the Commission will assume what the Ombudsman requests and what the Parliament recommends based on what the Ombudsman has requested.
Mr. President, I believe that the proposed Regulations submitted to us by the Commission are important and necessary, and, on the other hand, it was also important and necessary that from the
We insisted on the principles on which the two rapporteurs for the European Parliament, Mr. Swieske and Mr. Deprez, have also insisted—namely, the principle of community competition.

This concerns a matter of community competence in which, for practical reasons, it is advisable to retain certain powers of the Member States, but, as Mr. Barrot has stated, limited in scope and in duration.
Community competence is unavailable, and neither the Council, nor the Commission, nor the Parliament has the power to waive those community competencies.

Having established this, this is an exceptional procedure. I believe that the amendments we have discussed and presented, and which I believe will be approved by Parliament tomorrow, will allow for the approval of this package of measures in first reading.

However, I also expect that, from the Commission's side, moving forward and building on this, we can make progress in the development of a genuine European private law, which is increasingly necessary, as highlighted, for example, by Mr. Sógor in his most recent intervention.
We are discussing the problems that most directly affect people, and to the extent that we are able to resolve those people's problems, people will realize that the European Union has a function.

Ultimately, Mr. President, I would like to congratulate my colleagues, Mr. de Bray, and Mr. Lesbianska, and to thank the Commission and the Council for their willingness to collaborate with us on this matter.

Madam President, Commissioner, I signed this Resolution and requested to intervene in this matter because I was a witness to what was termed an expulsion, but was in reality the abduction of our colleague, Luis Herrero.

Furthermore, I was able to verify that political persecution, abuse of power by the Chavista regime, intimidation of the opposition, threats, disregard for the dignity of individuals, and the manipulative use of justice are standard practices in Venezuela, among other things.

The case of Manuel Chávez is the straw that broke the camel’s back and has given rise to this Resolution, but there are thousands of cases as egregious as his, cited in the Resolution, and others that are not.

As is the case with Igio Cedeño, who was born in the humble Caracas neighborhood of Petare, well known for its danger and, furthermore, because he voted for a mayor who was not from the Chavista regime.
Eligio studied thanks to the help of others and, specifically, Citibank, managed to found his own business, the Banco de Caracas, and, furthermore, later lived normally helping those most in need.
Today, however, he languishes in a Caracas prison illegally, after two years of having been detained without any charging plaintiff.
Their sole crime was being part of the economic oligarchy.

Another case is that of Nilson Moreno, a student leader from the Universidad de los Andes, elected on several occasions to the University Council and president of the Federación de Centros Universales.
In 2003, the current Minister of Interior and Justice won the election for the Federation, and this is his transgression.
Today he stands accused of frustrated homicide, lewd acts, and violent acts, among other things, despite having been cleared of such accusations.

Situations like yours are commonplace in this country, where the persecution of opponents, with the aim of excluding them from political life and discouraging dissent, have become everyday occurrences.

However, from here it is necessary to send a message of hope to Venezuelan democracy. Despite the difficulties, I am certain that democracy will prevail and that President Chávez will be defeated at the polls.

Madam President, Commissioner, indeed, it is undeniable that progress has been made recently, but, despite all that has been achieved, the southern part of the Union is burning and burning more and more.
Therefore, the resolution adopted by this Parliament cannot be merely a resolution designed to highlight the great concern caused to us by the misfortunes of others.
Wildfires occur for various reasons, but no one can deny that they are fueled by climate change.

And, irrespective of any responsibilities that may exist in certain States or in certain autonomous communities, the reality is that this Parliament must clearly call on the Commission to act with expediency and to deploy all the resources at its disposal, which are not few.
Neither the victims, nor the damages suffered, nor the reforestation needs understand bureaucracy, nor can they comprehend budgetary shortfalls.
We must prioritize and we must act, and acting, in this case, involves modifying strategies, mobilizing resources, increasing them, and optimally coordinating preventive policies, demanding the

In any case, responsibilities would accrue to States lacking them, but assuming this is not a problem for some Southern European States and that climate change does not affect only some States, but all, and is a common cause.
Therefore, one of the principal tasks facing this Parliament in the near term must be to ensure that the European Union secures clear commitments at the upcoming Copenhagen Summit.

and decisive in order to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions as much as possible, because they are evidently at the foundation of the fires, of their causes, and these, in turn, in the causes of further climate change.
Therefore, approving this Resolution is now the challenge for this Parliament, certainly.
But let that challenge set by the Commission be fulfilled if, truly, Commissioner, you want to prevent the south of the Union, which does exist, from continuing to burn.
Mr. President, thank you very much for granting me the floor. I am addressing Mr. Barroso.

Mr. Barroso, I must tell you that I have followed you with great interest and with profound respect for a long time, since you were a leader in a country that is very close to us and very dear, which is Portugal.
I must tell you, however, that you have me utterly astonished at present.

I am surprised for two reasons. Firstly, you have demonstrated a disregard for the Group in which I am present, the Group of Non-Affiliated Members, by not granting us even a minute of your time to come and tell us about your political proposals.
We represent many European citizens, and you have demonstrated a disregard for all of our electors.
Secondly, due to the fragility of their political project, and the poverty of their political proposals in the document "Political Orientations for the Next Commission."
proposals that do not even manage to encompass what you have defended throughout your own term as President of the Commission.
It has surprised me, in this regard, that matters such as energy, which have been well handled throughout your tenure, are now, when you offer us your contributions for the next

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, you concluded your remarks by telling us that there is a crisis in the dairy sector, but you began them by telling us that you had already taken all necessary measures and that the situation was being resolved.
Look, correcting is the mark of the wise.
And that is a Spanish saying that could very well be applied to the case at hand today.

The dairy sector has been experiencing one of the most serious crises in its history for months, and despite this, due to an unwillingness to concede, either the European Commission or some of the governments—including, it appears and also includes mine, the Spanish Government—refuse to reverse the decisions of the health check of the CAP.
Those decisions were adopted without considering the fragility of this sector and in a market context very different from the one that emerged after that commitment was fulfilled.
It gives the impression that Member States either did not want to or were unable to see the approaching storm at that time.
The reform quickly became outdated due to the significant shift in the market—a shift that demonstrates the sector's complete vulnerability to price volatility.

That major producers such as France and Germany, countries that secured the largest absolute increase in their national production quotas under that agreement, are now the ones requesting a review of the check decisions, is food for thought.

In my understanding, the Member States erred and should have listened more attentively to the voices, among which I count myself, that were calling for a postponement of any definitive decision regarding the sector's future until 2011.
It is a shame that they did not listen to us.
If you hear a sound, do so now.
Mr. President, this Parliament is a palace of chimera, it is a palace of dreams.
The Irish people, with their strong vote, give us encouragement and strength to continue prospering and building a strong Europe and, above all, a federal Europe.
Only thus would we deserve the title of legitimate heirs to the founders of Europe, through whose work we all are here.

Mr. President, having overcome the concerns generated by the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon, it is, in my opinion, time to consider the treatment that should be given in the future to the nationalist attitudes that so hinder European construction.
My idea is that these impediments cannot come without a cost.
With a clear head, it is time to consider the possible measures to adopt in the coming days and years.
This modest deputy desires a future President of the Council who is a man, or better yet a woman, convinced of European federalism, and capable of managing the
euro that is located within the Schengen Area and that is identified with and committed to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union.
Madam Commissioner, that is to say, on behalf of the Commission, I have nothing further to add, amen, but well, I had already prepared an intervention on behalf of the Socialist Group.

The breakdown of the constitutional order in Honduras breaks two decades without coups in Latin America and creates a perverse precedent for other countries, particularly the more vulnerable ones, as is now the case with Paraguay.
The European Parliament cannot and should not remain deaf and mute in the face of such a violation of the rule of law.

Both the Council and the Commission have unequivocally condemned the coup, supporting the mediation efforts of President Arias, in line with the position adopted unanimously by the OAS with the backing of the United Nations.

The self-proclaimed de facto president Michelette has failed to abide by the recently reached agreements, ridiculing the international community and preventing, among other measures, the return of the incumbent president, Mr. Celaya, to office.

Under the current circumstances, the election of a new president in the polls scheduled for November 29th suffers from a defect in its origin, and its results cannot and should not be recognized by the international community.

The European Parliament would commit a serious error if it were to send a delegation to observe the elections, as this would be interpreted as an endorsement of the coup d'état. The OAS has already ruled out sending an observation mission to these elections.
This Parliament has distinguished itself as a guarantor of freedom, democracy, the rule of law, and respect for human rights.
As Bachelard Havel mentioned this morning, there cannot be two weights or two measures.

We are all democrats here, and consequently, proponents of freedom; therefore, let us speak of Cuba, of China, of North Korea, or, now, of Honduras—our discourse must be firm in the face of those who extinguish liberty.
Let us not be blinded by our ideological preferences.
There are no right-wing or left-wing coup plotters or dictators, only liberty-killers and repressors.

Many of us fear that things in Honduras will not change, and with that, a very dangerous precedent will have been created, and the doctrine of the “good,” temporary, and not overly cruel coup will have triumphed.

Mr. President, I would like to congratulate the members of the Denby Committee and its chairman, Mr. Lehne, for the work they have done to allow us to have a resolution such as the one we have and which we must approve decisively.
We cannot settle for simply stating that sector-specific agreements are sufficient, because speaking of a patchwork agreement already acknowledges a portion of the failure.
We must proceed to approve this Resolution, which has three noble aspirations.
A more evident one is avoiding climate change with concrete proposals for emissions reduction and a commitment to funding, aspiring to a binding agreement, not a piecemeal one.

And two latent aspirations: one, to begin earlier rather than later to work towards a common energy policy, as we once endowed ourselves with a common agricultural policy, because it was necessary, and the other, of course, which is also included, to regain the confidence of citizens in politics and in politicians—something Europe is not overflowing with.
In that sense, the success of the summit will be the success of the three aspirations.
Therefore, I encourage the acting President of the Council to maintain his optimism, to press and negotiate as much as possible to bring others along to this success.

I do not know if the leaders of this multipolar world wish to be discredited by history for failing to reach a binding agreement, but I, as a parliamentarian, and I believe all representatives of the peoples, cannot be discredited by history for having failed, in Copenhagen, to achieve the binding commitment we have with humanity to avoid climate change.

Mr. President, there is no doubt today of the European Union’s commitment to the fight against terrorism, and thanks to the Stockholm Treaty, the Stockholm Programme, we will continue to advance in this space of freedom, justice, and security that is so necessary.

In my view, this struggle has been based on mutual trust among the Member States, but the time has come, with the possibilities offered by the Treaty of Lisbon, to harmonize national legislations in the direction of the non-prescription of terrorist offenses, which should be considered crimes against humanity.

The day this occurs, no one in this Parliament or any other will defend terrorists, as has happened, is happening, and may continue to happen, with the consequent harm to victims of terrorism, who see how those who murdered their loved ones are treated as heroes, while they suffer in silence.
I therefore request that this Parliament promote or adopt the European Charter on the Rights of Victims of Terrorism, based on the defense of memory.

Mr. President, I would first like to congratulate Mrs. McGuinness on this initiative, which highlights the important role played by the CAP in addressing the needs for food supply on an international scale.

Now that the European Commission appears to want to reduce the weight of the CAP within the community budget, it must be stated very clearly that the CAP is no longer a priority, but food sufficiency should be. In past decades, it has been seen that without the CAP, food sufficiency is very difficult, if not impossible, to achieve.
Therefore, agriculture cannot be compared with other sectors of the economy capable of thriving in a free market, because the food market is not a free market.

The farmer needs the backing of the European Union to be able to move his business forward, and the Union, in turn, needs the farmer to maintain an agricultural model capable of providing sufficient and quality food to an increasingly demanding citizen.
Therefore, I believe a shift in direction of the CAP would need to occur, but not its disappearance.

To achieve this, it would be necessary to guarantee direct subsidies to farmers, in addition to re-establishing a market management policy that provides greater price stability, which would have a positive impact not only on farmers, but also on consumers and third-country nations.

It would be necessary to establish a framework of best practices to foster balanced relationships among the various actors in the food supply chain, avoiding abusive practices and promoting a more equitable distribution of commercial margins.
Furthermore, a consumer information policy is needed for European consumers that emphasizes the efforts made by Community producers to comply with European Union regulations regarding
environment, food security, and animal welfare, because community producers have to compete with productions from third countries, where, for imports, much lower standards are applied.

And those producers from third countries prefer to export to the European Union rather than supply their own domestic markets for a matter of genuine profitability, with the backing of WTO negotiations.
Mr. President, according to a United Nations report, approximately 270 individuals were victims of human trafficking in the European Union in 2009.
