With these figures in hand, it is necessary that the action of the European Union be primarily based on the protection of victims, with particular attention to the situation of women and children, who are the most vulnerable.
We cannot continue to stand idly by while witnessing this spectacle, this display of sexual exploitation unfolding before our eyes.
Therefore, I fully support this Parliament’s request that assistance to victims be unconditional, more substantial, and that harsher penalties be imposed, as Mr. Barrot just stated.
Having said this, I would like to request the Presidency and the Council to utilize all European legislation at their disposal, both existing and future, to protect victims of human trafficking.

I believe that the proposal for a European protection order for victims, which I personally requested from the Spanish Presidency during the debates of the Stockholm Programme and which has finally been implemented, will be an effective instrument for combating these crimes.

I await a firm commitment, as we have already seen, from the Spanish Presidency, so that this order offers victims special protection measures that are effective throughout the territory of the European Union.

I hope that those of us with the responsibility to act on the most serious problems facing our society will provide a real and concrete response to this grave problem of human trafficking and that we do not remain alone with fine words.
We truly owe it to all the victims.
Mr. President, Mr. Zapatero, for a Spaniard, as I am, it is an honor to greet your presence here in your capacity as president of the European Union.
There are numerous expectations and challenges inherent in this period, and of course, we cannot fail to meet the expectations that have been created.
May the citizenry see that our renewed institutions are an instrument capable of providing solutions to real-world problems.
But the report presented by your Lordship is one we share.
That for the People's Party of Spain, this is a matter of state, and that we will stand behind Your Lordship in everything we see to be common interests of Europe and that is important for Spain.
It is an ambitious program, and it is a program that, hopefully, will be filled with content.

I would like it so that in that album of the Spanish Presidency, people can see – since it will surely be colorful and varied – that in each event they see a landmark concerning real problems that affect them.
The crisis is hitting economies, and unemployment appears like a fifth horseman of the apocalypse.
You have had the honesty to acknowledge that a 20% unemployment rate exists in Spain, but that does not incapacitate you.
What I believe is that it obligates all of us to produce, collectively, a solution or problem—really, a problem that we must solve together.
That is a real problem.
Time does not permit me to say many things, Mr. President.

However, I do want to say that Spain faces many challenges ahead, challenges that I believe—I am certain—demonstrate Spain's capabilities as a nation, and I want to believe and am confident that you will rise to the occasion for our country.

We cannot disappoint Europe’s expectations at this moment. On the other hand, the globalized world—as has been astutely observed—fosters the emergence of new power centers, and it is necessary that the European Union plays a more active and coherent role in the defense of its values and interests.
Otherwise, we risk becoming irrelevant.
Finally, Mr. President, Spaniards do not accept that anyone deny us the capacity to make proposals.
We possess that legitimacy.
We must also possess the humility to accept those pieces of advice from Don Quixote that Sancho gave him when he recommended humility in the dreaming of governing the Island of Barataria.
I am pleased to say that José Luis Zapatero has continued to surprise European women with measures of great innovation and progress.
Certainly, the formation of a genuinely balanced government and the courageous manner in which it has brought the issues of gender equality and respect for others onto the European national agenda.
Mr. President, I warmly congratulate you on your ambitious action program, certainly against gender-based violence, which is a social scourge.
The creation of a European observatory on gender-based violence is a pioneering proposal that European women support and applaud.
Mr. President, on behalf of the Portuguese socialists, I wish you good luck.
Can you count on our solidarity?
solidarity, women with a shoemaker.
Mr. President, in a matter as serious as terrorism, we should not wait for events to unfold before taking action.
We should anticipate this, but we do not.
And, unfortunately, we are progressing through acts of aggression, much like the failed Trojan attack, which compels us today to make decisions that guarantee the safety of air transport.
Deciding on the use of body scanners in airports is a responsibility that we cannot evade, ladies and gentlemen.
We cannot continue waiting, because terrorists do not wait.
Therefore, the Commission must as soon as possible guarantee us that the dignity and privacy of individuals will be preserved and that there will be no adverse effects on health.
Granted this, we must adopt decisions for the entire European Union.

And to those who fear that fundamental rights will be violated, I will say that there is no higher right than the right to live, and those of us who love freedom above all else need to live securely in order to feel truly free.
Mr. President, I believe this crisis is an opportunity to move forward firmly and with conviction in the creation of a strong Europe.

In that strong Europe, it is likely that the expression "improve coordination" should be dispensed with, as it makes everything dependent on the subjects to be coordinated and, strictly speaking, refers to paralysis and indefiniteness.
We know that the finances and public debts of European countries will suffer until progress is made towards European financial integration and eurobonds are not issued.

In any case, European institutions can already undertake concrete actions—I will not reiterate the rhetoric of coordination—and there they are, on the one hand, the European Central Bank to harmonize financial supervision and
Mr. President, I want to state that I have not come to this Parliament to applaud the recently enacted law in Spain regarding abortion.

What concerns me is human life, and I am particularly concerned, and I am here to defend women whose lives are endangered by gender-based violence and to offer them a space where they can live free and safely.

This Parliament’s Resolution of 2 February 2006 recommends that Member States adopt a zero-tolerance approach with regard to all forms of violence against women and that they adopt the necessary measures to ensure better protection for victims.

The Stockholm Programme, approved in this Chamber, established an area of freedom, justice, and security for all European citizens, and it considered the fight against gender-based violence a priority.

It reflected my request to the Spanish Presidency that it promote, during its term, a European protection order for victims of gender-based violence to ensure that victims of these crimes enjoy the same level of protection in all Member States.

In a Europe without borders, the fight against gender-based violence should also have no borders, and Member States should strive, when harmonizing their legislation, to ensure that the fight against abuse towards women surpasses national boundaries.

Therefore, I urge the Commission and the Council to do everything possible to ensure that the Commission and the Council strive to uphold the rules of the European Union regarding the rights of women and children.

everything necessary and everything within its power to ensure the success of this European order for the protection of victims, which is a very effective instrument for combating the impunity of those who do not respect the dignity of women or their right to live free and safe.

It has been a long time since Fidel Castro and his oligarchy ended the ideals of the Cuban Revolution, which resonated so profoundly and inspired such hope for the peoples of the world, for the brightest of international youth.
What characterizes, however, the Castro brothers’ dictatorship at this moment is the impiety towards political and conscientious prisoners, the impiety against their own people.
It reminds me of Franco, with the mistreatment of political prisoners he also considered common, his own obsessive disdain for the exiled.
Castro ends up as Franco and all enemies of freedom when they become entrenched in power.
But we must save lives and be supportive of those who struggle and suffer.
It is our obligation as Europeans committed to democracy, freedom, and human rights.
Madam President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. Commissioner, let us never again allow our silence to become complicity with those who curtail freedom.

Let us never again permit a person who was fighting for their rights and the rights of all to die in a Cuban prison or any other place without our voice rising, strong and firm, demanding their salvation.

Mr. Orlando Zapata Tamayo, a 42-year-old man of color, a bricklayer who was only requesting improvements to prison conditions, died after 86 days of a hunger strike and seven years in prison for demanding respect for human rights.
And in those seven years, he was mistreated, humiliated, and ill-treated by his jailers, amidst, it must be remembered, a dense silence from the international community.
Other prisoners and human rights activists in Cuba are now on hunger strike, including the psychologist and journalist Guillermo Fariñas.

Honorable Members, the Resolution we present today, that we debate today, and that we will vote on tomorrow, and which I represent on behalf of the Social Democratic Group, demands the release of all prisoners of conscience in Cuba.
It reiterates, once again, its support for a democratic transition and the strict respect for fundamental human rights.
Let us not, for the moment, enter into a topic that divides us, regarding whether or not to maintain the common position.
Let us now focus on the topic of saving lives and human rights.
And we speak of a period of serene reflection in which we seek points of convergence on the themes of Cuba’s future politics.
But this text also possesses a significant added value.
The fact that it is being presented by six political groups expresses a new era of broad consensus in this Chamber on the issue of human rights.

Let it never again be asserted that democratic right-wing parties in Europe bend to the dictates of American imperialism, but let it also never again be said that social democrats are accommodating or complicit with communist dictatorships.
Simply because both assertions are false, and the victims of these liberticides, wherever they may be, must know that they will find us united in the unconditional defense of their cause.

Mr. President, I would like, finally, to thank Mr. Salafranca, who negotiated this text on behalf of the European People's Party, Ms. Weber from the Alliance of Conservatives and Liberals Group, and Mr.

Mr. Romévez, on behalf of the Green Group, to Mr. Kasutnik, from the European Conservatives and Reformists, and to other colleagues who have participated in this difficult, complicated, but I hope tomorrow successful endeavor.

And finally, I would also like to thank the Prime Minister of Spain and President of the European Union’s rotating presidency, Mr. José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, for his encouragement and support in moving forward this resolution that we are debating today.
History will absolve me was the famous plea of a young lawyer who stirred his people.
History, in effect, absolves her of her rebellion against tyranny and subsequently against the North American blockade.
Yet, with the same emphatic condemnation, this Parliament, representing the largest space of freedom and democracy in the world, condemns the dictatorship.
What does the Cuban people suffer? The violation of human rights on the island? The cruelty towards political prisoners? The disdain for its exiled nationals?
The judgment of history is clear.
With this Resolution, members of parliament from all ideologies, we stand alongside the Cubans who are fighting.
One must avoid at all possible means the brutal repression they suffer, even surpassing the paralyzing call of common position.
Tribute to the poet Raúl Rivero in the last verse of his Habana. Do not impose taxes on affection, emptiness, asphyxiation, bitterness.
The ruins of the homeland are secure.
Calm down, colleagues.
We're leaving now.
This week, International Women's Day was celebrated.
In this Parliament, we saw many posters in all the languages of the European Union stating that, yes, violence against women can be eradicated.

Today we are discussing violence in Mexico, and it seems normal to acknowledge that Mexican women, both indigenous and non-indigenous, are the least protected victims by local and federal authorities.
Mexican women are victims of all forms of violence, from domestic violence to sexual violence and torture perpetrated by military or police personnel, and even homicide.
Regrettably, thus far, the responses from Mexican authorities have been ineffective, and for that reason, it is correctly spoken of near absolute impunity.
Our resolution calls on the Mexican Government to combat feminicides—a harsh but accurate term when we see that almost all murders committed against women remain unpunished.
An example in the State of Mexico is that, in the last four years, only 11 of the criminals who murdered nearly 700 women were convicted.
At the same time, it appears that women are the preferred victims of the judicial system.
There is no other way to explain how it was possible for two Indigenous women, Alberta Alcántara and Teresa González, to be sentenced to twenty-one years in prison and until
Now more than three years have passed in prison, for kidnappings and robberies, during an incident in a market, six men from the Federal Investigation Agency.
I hope the judge, who will decide in a week on the appeal in this case, realizes the absurdity and injustice of the situation. But violence against women begins in the family.

I hope that Mexican legislators will soon improve the General Law on Women’s Access to a Life Free of Violence so that the types of violence and the mechanisms that will make the regulations cooperative are defined.
Similarly, it would be normal to establish that domestic violence and marital rape are criminal offenses.
Furthermore, for Mexican society to change and reject violence against women, it is important that in schools this topic becomes a primary concern of young people’s education.
Madam President, the truth is that the first thing I would like to do this evening is to thank Mr. Scotty for his excellent willingness to negotiate this report.
It has been a genuine pleasure working with him and with the other spokespersons for the parliamentary groups.

We are proud of the position that will be demonstrated tomorrow in the vote in this European Parliament, and we are proud of a position like this one that defends quality, that champions the development and enhancement of rural areas, not only as

I do not witness, as numerous observers of a traditional European culture do, but as genuine generators of wealth and employment—employment that we so sorely lack now in these times of economic crisis and the dramatic employment situation in some Member States.

We also appreciate the defense maintained by this European Parliament and that position already held, which the Committee on Agriculture has made clear, of advocating for quality to the highest degree.
And, at that maximum level, we definitively advocate for maintaining that differentiation between protected designations of origin and protected geographical indications.
Certainly, we reject the ideas of lowering quality standards and want attention to be given to, and value placed on, community production.
I applaud Commissioner Cholo’s words.
It certainly was pleasant to listen to him speak about the commitment to the future of the European agricultural sector.
Certainly, we hope you will heed the voice of this Parliament, which will be made clear tomorrow in that vote.

Finally, I would like to state that we hope it never happens again that the European Commission preempts this Parliament by prohibiting things such as, for example, marketing standards for fruits and vegetables, which have done so much damage to European free competition.
We want market imbalances to correct themselves, and we also want to invest in quality, variety, food safety, and an adequate level of production.
We also want community productions and the quality of those community agro-food products to be defended within the World Trade Organization.
And for that, we also count, of course, on the work of Commissioner Cholos, because neither our producers nor our European consumers can remain defenseless.
Mr. President, the Commissioner has spoken of the absurdity and obsolescence of the procedures.
Let us, then, be consistent.
We have lost too many opportunities, too many agreements to introduce community competition over European airspace.
But if we were unable to intervene as we should have in the sky, we could certainly do so in the skin of the earth.
for example, monitoring passenger rights and also mediating or calling for a truce in the various collective conflicts of land transportation
No minimum services, maximum services to all parties.
Madam President, when from distinct and distant positions, like those of Mauro, Kolnitz, or Kolmann, one reaches the conclusion that there is no
The procedure, the electoral systems, the election of Members of the European Parliament present problems; that means, Madam President, that we need a uniform electoral procedure.

that was a mandate already established in the Treaties of Rome and therefore the coordinators—and I want to take this opportunity to express my gratitude to everyone, but especially to Mr. Gaudí and Mr. Daf—have agreed to an amendment.

2002 Tomorrow, it will be voted upon, and I hope that this Chamber will support it precisely so that this matter, this question of uniform electoral procedure, assigned to the European Parliament, can be resolved by us shortly.
It seems to me that with that, we would eliminate this type of query.
In his address, Mr. Trzaskowski spoke of the necessary representativeness of this Chamber, and this is a factor that the majority of speakers, including Vice-President Šefčovič, have highlighted.
Of course, I agree, and we state this in the report, in article 1, that the eighteen enter as a bloc, because if they didn’t, we would lose representativeness.

And for them to act as a bloc, to fulfill that act of political justice that is the Lisbon Agreement, we must, ladies and gentlemen, be pragmatic, because a transitional and exceptional situation also requires transitional and exceptional solutions.

And that is why I do not conceal it: I do not like the possibility of deputies entering this Chamber who did not emerge from the 2009 elections. I say this with complete clarity in paragraph 2, but if I have to choose between that and not…

If it enters into force at 18 or seeks a pragmatic solution that enters into force at 18 and we comply, therefore, with the Lisbon Agreement, I ask this Chamber—and that is the basis of my report—to opt for that transitional, pragmatic, but above all, Madam President, just solution.
Many thanks to everyone for the collaboration and for the interesting contributions made to this work.

As I was unable to do on March 11th, International Day of Victims of Terrorism, I would today, from this Parliament, wish to pay them a well-deserved tribute that recognizes the enormous sacrifice of those who have paid the highest price in the name of freedom.

It is urgent to begin work on a Directive that protects the rights of victims of terrorism, who are always the forgotten ones and endure the humiliation of being unjustly equated with their perpetrators.
It is now time for these European institutions to recognize the dignity of victims of terrorism and to assist them in their right to protection and justice, which is swiftly translated into law.

that will honor all those who make it possible and that the first article, recognizing the right to justice for victims of terrorism, be the one established, and that no government ever pay a political price.

I issue a call to all those who can defend victims, never to forget that true peace is born of justice, and it is the only peace that we, those who believe in it, must defend from Europe and from any place in the world.

Mr. President, it has been necessary, Mr. President, to find ourselves on the brink of the abyss and economic collapse for the Heads of State and Government to understand that the path forward is not one of more nationalism, but one of more Europe.
At this juncture, measures have been implemented, such as the decline of the veto right in the European Council or the genesis of a European public asset.
Finally, albeit belatedly, we have become aware that we are all sailing in the same boat and that addressing individual situations is futile, and furthermore, doing so in an improvised manner.

But I wonder if this attitude is a parenthesis or, conversely, the beginning of a genuine European economic governance, because what is lacking, dear colleagues, is governance and what is missing is authentic government if we are to remain faithful to the testament of the founding fathers.

Therefore, from this Parliament, we must promote all those reforms aimed at strengthening Europe and making budgetary and fiscal discipline a reality, forgetting, incidentally, nostalgic sovereignties.

Distinguished members, colleagues, strengthening the European Commission and strengthening this Parliament is the only sound recipe for building a Europe that, otherwise, would vanish like a fleeting shadow.
Mr. President, Commissioner, from the Inta Commission, thank you to Mrs. Sarney for the collaboration we have had.
Now more than ever, the Union for the Mediterranean is necessary, along with the strengthening of major projects and institutional development.
Now more than ever, it is necessary to find solutions to the exit from the crisis, to research, to climate change, to water, to new energy models, to sustainable development.

To achieve this, it is necessary to promote and finalize commercial and economic relationships in the region with short- and long-term measures: a free trade zone, elimination of tariff barriers, and the opening of the North-South and South-South markets.
The Barcelona Summit, the Spanish Presidency, will offer the possibility of a new commitment, a new situation, a new exchange of views, and the democratization of economic and social solutions.
The Barcelona Summit could position us to lead the Mediterranean.
Madam President, within the Trans-European Transport Networks lies the railway corridor known as the Mediterranean Corridor.
It is a vital communication that will link North Africa with Europe.
For Spain, it is vital because this axis is a priority, given that it would connect Algeciras with Europe.
Without being excluded from other priority corridors, it would pass through Almería, Murcia, the Valencian Community, and Catalonia.
And why did Commissioner Reding say it? She stated increased economic activity and a high concentration of ground transportation.
This is one of the two conditions.
The possibility of communicating with various ports in the Mediterranean area opened up.
Economic momentum must be gained, competitiveness was also emphasized by the commissioner, because in this region, over 50% of Spanish exports originate.
Therefore, if we expand the scope of a strategic railway axis through the Mediterranean, we will increase competitiveness for Spain and greater competitiveness for Europe.
Madam President, I wanted to take this minute to congratulate the rotating Spanish presidency for the efforts it has made this semester to overcome the crisis.
a common position regarding Cuba and create a new type of relationship between the European Union and Cuba that includes, naturally and as a priority, the defense of human rights.
That policy has not been crowned with success, due primarily to the intransigence of the Cuban dictatorship that began this Presidency, precisely in January of
This year, with the expulsion of the member of parliament addressing you, when he attempted to visit, with all the visas and full legality, the island to be concerned about human rights there.
But that policy, that new policy undertaken by the Spanish Government, will yield results sooner rather than later.

Mr. President, Commissioner, colleagues, this is a Regulation of utmost importance for consumers and the agri-food industry, because it is far from easy to achieve balanced labeling that contains everything essential, but is not so exhaustive as to complicate the information.
This is an excellent report, and the presenter deserves congratulations for it.
I agree with her on the major issues pertaining to nutritional information and the contentious topic of profiles, especially if we take into account that the Commission did not fulfill
the commitment to establish these profiles, along with their terms of use, before January 19, 2009, as stipulated by Regulation No. 1924

There is a matter that concerns me, and it is the possibility of coherence in national regulations for labeling, because it runs counter to the objective of the legislation, which is harmonization and to avoid all possible obstacles to the functioning of a genuine single market.
Regarding the indication of country of origin, current legislation stipulates that this information must be provided when, in the absence of such indication, it could mislead the consumer.
Furthermore, voluntary labeling is always anticipated.
But going further can entail economic costs and administrative complexity for companies, without providing any significant benefit, clearly, to the consumer.
And, regarding the use of different languages, I must say that the Commission's proposal aligns with the existing Directive, which has functioned well and has not presented problems.
And reopening this debate can prove both dangerous and necessary, potentially causing disruptions to the flow of goods.
Mr. President, the best demonstration of our good faith is the thousand amendments we are seeing from the Committee to the Full Chamber.

However, beyond good intentions, I believe we must be practical when labeling foods if we do not want to achieve the opposite effect of what we are pursuing, that is, confusing the consumer instead of helping them to become informed.
It is not a matter of illustrating, but of preventing, of informing about what can be eaten and to what extent.
It is necessary to label regarding fats, regarding sugars, regarding trans fats.
Indeed.
We are, indeed, discussing that which affects cholesterol, all those substances that affect what we have said—obesity and the health of individuals.

Yes, but other foods, with other information—such as place of origin, when it does not lead to confusion, or, for example, in meat, specifying the place of birth, the place of transit, the grazing location, and the place of slaughter for cattle—can be very illustrative, but they will ultimately cause confusion.

It is up to us to ensure that we are practical and that this Regulation is remembered as the one that will harmonize and inform consumers, or, conversely, as the one that will confuse them more and impose matters that, far from achieving better health outcomes, will result in greater degrees of confusion.

Therefore, I suggest, for example, that some of us opt for GDA, the guideline daily amount, instead of traffic light systems, because it is very clear that if you consume this amount or double it, you will gain weight; therefore, consume only one.
The amount of daily intake versus all types of codes is what some of us propose, to avoid further confusing the consumer.
Madam President, thank you very much, Mr. Martín Fraguero, for being here, on behalf of the Spanish Presidency, in a report like this, Madam Commissioner for Foreign Affairs.
Mr. Milana, congratulations on the ability to reach a common agreement and to converge all interests, and to place on the table an initiative report, one of the first initiative reports.
The deployment of aquaculture is important.

It is necessary due to the increase in fish consumption and the stagnation of fishing extraction capacity, but I want to highlight, at this moment, the economic importance of this activity, which generates economic wealth and creates employment.
It is important to uphold health guarantees, it is important to ensure sustainability, and it is important to protect the marine environment.
It is necessary to strengthen the image of aquaculture and also to strengthen the scientific and research sector.
Aquaculture represents an opportunity, as Mr. Martin Frareiro stated within the PCP, as the Commissioner was saying.

It is necessary to provide it with a coherent framework for coordination, to give it the possibility of regularization, because aquaculture can represent sufficiency, sustainability, and economic resources, and I believe that it is important for Europe.

Mr. President, in my opinion, this excellent report outlines the guiding principles that should inspire the new Transport White Paper, which will shape European transport policy for the next ten years.

This report features several key milestones worth noting: the necessity of a financial fund as an indispensable instrument, the challenge of the increasing demand for freight transport, and the search for cost-effective solutions that
the pressing need for sufficient and safe rest areas in road transport, the diagnosis, in my considered opinion, that a mere competition between different sectors should not be allowed.

not to compete with one another, but rather to complement each other by seeking efficiency criteria. The speaker's assertion, which I consider brave and just, that rail or maritime transport is not always more environmentally respectful than road transport.
Ultimately, the concept of an efficient community is a concept of the future and, without a doubt, should be supported, in my view, with all rigor.
Is yours, Mr. President, a fundamental error?
Did you truly believe you would preside over Europe and influence the mechanisms that drive the complex European machinery?
He even came to believe, indeed, because that is how he allowed those close to you to proclaim it, that the world was going to live under his Presidency a moment of brilliance.
None of this has come to fruition.
Let us proceed to some clarifications.

Over these six months of the Spanish Presidency, I would like to distinguish, on the one hand, between its political direction and, on the other, the work of the officials who have been working behind the scenes.
It is the first [initiative] that has failed, and this is due to the lack of adequate impetus from the Presidency of the Government, which has rather swung like a pendulum.
However, I wish to highlight the effort of the officials, their valuable willingness to serve Europe and Spain.
And it is the case, Mr. President, that Spain has magnificent professional civil servants, and if there is something to lament, it is that they are marginalized too much in daily reality.
Having said this, it is necessary to acknowledge that some commendable initiatives have been adopted in these six months.
Among these, I am pleased to cite the organ donation and transplantation plan and the treatment given to the rights of patients in cross-border healthcare.
More issues remain unresolved regarding the agreements on the new 2020 Strategy and, above all, those concerning the European External Action Service, both still too fragile.
It has been regrettable what has happened with the European order for the protection of victims of gender-based violence, and the same somber outcome has been presented by the
A European patent, fundamental to the life of thousands of businesses and partly hampered by the linguistic issues that Spanish legislation encourages.

But it is all major political actions that have been indelibly linked to spectacular failures. From the Mediterranean Summit to that of the European Union with the United States, the latter is cited regarding which its own Government was responsible for creating excessive expectations.
However, we must concede that the inability to advance its policy regarding Cuba has been highly positive for Cubans.
Finally, the advances made on the path towards better European economic governance cannot in any way be attributed to its Presidency, clamorously absent in the most relevant matters.
Farewell, then, to the Spanish Presidency.

A positive conclusion I do want to draw from this experience is that my fantasy of a convinced Europeanist is excited at the thought that it may signify the end of rotating presidencies, as they have been conceived until now.

This would be welcome news, for as long as Europe does not strengthen its common institutions, firmly uniting its fragments, it will continue to run the risk of sinking into the empty spaces of irrelevance.
Mr. President, believe me, Mr. Zapatero, that I would have liked to deliver a different speech today.
He proposed, Your Honor, a semester brimming with ambition and set the bar so high in his aspirations that, when compared with what was actually achieved, disappointment is inevitable.
The truth is that Your Lordship has not been able to overcome a complex situation, for which leadership and credibility were needed.
Your Lordship has recalled that the European Union is a club with rules, and I concur.
But it was his Lordship to whom it belonged to demand compliance with those rules.
The reality is that it was the Government of Spain to whom they were imperatively demanding the fulfillment of its obligations.
In this instance, positive achievements have been overshadowed.
Your Honor has had time to recount them; I have not.
Democracy, ladies and gentlemen, is a regime of public opinion.
And that is what Obama's seeming disdain, the cancellation of the Mediterranean Summit, and the announced European Union to the United States appear to be: failures of considerable significance.
The rush to close improvised agreements at any price has not favored the image of Spanish management, which has been described as slapdash in the way it has sought to achieve respectable objectives.
Spain is a great nation and will remain so, despite poor management of this time.
Our diplomats and officials have held their own, and as a result, the prestige of Spain will endure.
The truth is that the judgment passed on this Presidency will weigh more heavily on Spain's situation than on what has or has not been done here.
It would be difficult for someone who has placed their country in a stage of uncertainty and unrest to lead such a challenging company.
Indeed, in the best of cases, this Presidency has proven sadly irrelevant.
Commissioner, esteemed members, in the coming months we will fully enter into the debate on the new CAP.

It is important to reach a good agreement, so I hope that the Belgian Presidency achieves what the Spanish Presidency did not, namely, to steer the discussions so that Member States commit to maintaining a policy also in the future.

Truly robust common agricultural policy, with a sufficient budget to address the needs of all twenty-seven Member States, both new and old, and avoid a situation like that of 2005, when funding was lacking and modulation had to be devised.

In the next reform of the CAP, we are staking the viability of a sector that not only contributes intangible goods and services, such as environmental stewardship, but should also ensure the provision of food to European citizens.

We have already witnessed painful situations of scarcity in the past, therefore it is necessary that the European Parliament provide security and supply based on community production as the principal objective of the next reform, without neglecting other contributions such as the fight against climate change.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, I concur with Commissioner Cholos that this report is necessary, very necessary, and comes at a timely moment, because the abuses committed by large-scale distribution have been demonstrated, severely disrupting the various links in the food supply chain.

The Bové report, which at times may go too far in its attempt to be overly interventionist, must nevertheless be recognized from the perspective of a social market economy, as we advocate for from the European People’s Party, as it provides responses to the legitimate claims of European producers.

Furthermore, it brings transparency to the different parts of the food chain, which is always beneficial, and provides greater possibilities and support for the weaker sectors of that chain to defend themselves, and unequivocally supports European consumers so that they can learn more about it.

Madam President, the European food industry could have been given more consideration within this report, perhaps it would have been very beneficial, but this report also includes measures to curb price volatility, and that was very necessary.
Measures are also included to ensure fairness for these links in the chain, as requested by the Environment Committee, and to combat unfair and disloyal practices by large-scale distribution.
It is now time to establish a list of abusive practices and for European legislation to definitively prohibit them.
It is also important to include measures to prevent anticompetitive practices through private label products, which are contrary to competition and contrary to the Intellectual Property Law.

For all these reasons, it is necessary to support Rapporteur Bové’s report and to support all colleagues who, from the various parliamentary committees—INCO, ENVI, or Agriculture—have demonstrated diligent work to ensure that this report finally sees the light of day and helps European producers thrive.
The alarm bell sounds, and it is true.
And the frustration is also audible, as can be heard in the interventions within this Plenary, due to the failure to achieve the Millennium Development Goals.
And the truth is that what we stand to lose is considerable.

Our natural environment is so fragile that, should the larger fish one day decide to cease consuming the smaller ones, we would have to pay for it all from the pockets of future generations, with our health and well-being as currency.
The European Union is a leader today in the fight against climate change and has been for some time in pioneering conservation measures.

However, as demonstrated by the unmet objectives, it appears that there has been a lack of will, not only for implementation and coordination – which have also been mentioned here – but also for expansion beyond our exceedingly limited special conservation areas.
Of course, biodiversity is not a museum piece that can be locked away in a ghettoized area, as sometimes appears to be the case, with occasional cursory glances.
Biodiversity thrives and has no borders; it traverses the entire Earth with a domino effect in which, if one piece falls, they all fall.

I draw attention to the need for global and more communal will, particularly regarding land, because subsidiarity, as the sole method for managing land or forests, may be one of the new formidable enemies of biodiversity.

Therefore, I draw attention to paragraph 67 and the potential vote that will be cast, and I urge you to reject the second part, because I am convinced that a common policy on land would help in the conservation of the entire territory.

A European world so varied, so diverse for good and ill, and so lacking in political will on the part of the individual states and so in need of ever greater European Union, with all the breadth of the word implying more Union also for the land.

Mr. President, Commissioner, first and foremost, I want to highlight the work of the rapporteur, Ms. McAvan, not only in terms of substance but also in terms of procedure, because she has done so in collaboration with all the shadow rapporteurs.
We also wish to thank the experts from the Spanish Administration for their contribution to this agreement.

The purpose of this European Union pharmacovigilance system is to strengthen the monitoring, transparency, and communication of the safety of food and medicines once they have been marketed, particularly with regard to their risk profiles and any adverse reactions they may produce.

It is important to highlight the creation of the European Pharmacovigilance Committee, which will evaluate and issue recommendations to the European Medicines Agency regarding safety issues that may arise with medicines marketed in the European Union.
It is very important the solution that has been reached for the enhanced monitoring notification of suspected beer-related reactions, both by Member States and by the marketing authorization holders.

Ultravigilance will be the sole source of information, but simultaneously, the competent authority of the Member State where the adverse reaction is suspected will be notified, and this is very important.
It is also important to highlight the possibility that opens up for consumers to communicate any adverse reaction, and in this regard, the creation and management by the Agency of a portal
and European on the safety of medicines, which in turn links to the portals of each Member State, will help improve citizens’ knowledge of the safety of the medicines they consume.
And finally, we cannot overlook the fact that, given that pharmacovigilance plays a crucial role in protecting public health, the approval of the Directive and the
This Directive and this Regulation will contribute significantly to that end, by improving not only current procedures but also the coordination of actions among the various Member States.

Mr. President, I greatly appreciate the rapporteur's effort to accept some suggestions and, of course, her defense of copyright, which I share, but the inclusion of the infringing and sanctionable nature of certain exchanges and the

Recognition of sanctioning authority for suppliers, as well as in the alternative resolution, the exclusion of mass exchanges as a possible infringement, makes a favorable vote on either of the two reports impossible in Liza.

The Gallo report has generated considerable interest and could have been timely, but the core of the debate is too deeply entrenched in the pro versus con discussion surrounding the French law known as
Pi, a disconnection from internet access for offenders, without a genuine European debate having yet taken place that considers the reality of other advancements in national legislation.

I hope we achieve a common position within the Socialist Group and a majority in the European Parliament on the debates and amendments regarding the Commission’s proposal for a Directive, which Commissioner Barnier has announced will shortly be submitted to Parliament.

On that occasion, we will seek to achieve a more balanced position than the one we have today, one that takes into account both the rights of Internet users and the essential respect for intellectual property.
Mr. President, I congratulate those who have worked on this report, on this financial package, especially the officials and the members of this Parliament.
It has taken a financial crisis of enormous proportions for Europe to awaken.
However, an opportunity has been lost, in part, to strengthen Europe’s common institutions, because, on the one hand, these new supervisory authorities have a scope of competence
limited compared to similar authorities of Member States, and it is regrettable that progress has not been made toward an integration similar to that which occurred with the system of central banks.
We have made progress, but it is necessary to continue climbing the mountain.

Madam President, as a member of the Committee on Human Rights, as a Spanish and European citizen, and as a victim of terrorism since the terrorist organization ETA murdered my brother and his wife in Seville, I address this Parliament to denounce the Government of Venezuela and its president for having allowed terrorists from

The officers are being trained within Venezuela under the orders of the alleged terrorist Cubilla, who works for the government of Hugo Chávez, despite the existence of an international warrant for his arrest, which constitutes a serious violation of the fundamental right to security of any European citizen.
I demand that the Government of Spain take decisive action in response to this grave humiliation of all Spaniards.
The Minister of Interior cannot remain silent while the Venezuelan ambassador calls our Civil Guard torturers, who have been and will be an example of bravery in the fight against ETA.
It cannot turn a blind eye to this growing cooperation between ETA and the FARC on Venezuelan soil, as already denounced by Judge Eloy Velasco.
Zapatero cannot shake hands with a leader like Chávez, who is turning Venezuela into a haven for terrorists.

The president of a country like Spain, where terrorism has caused so much pain, cannot continue to ignore this problem and should provide a response that it deserves and that any ordinary citizen would give if they had the opportunity to do so.
Mr. President, on February 14, 2008, as a Valentine’s Day gift, the Conference of Presidents decided that intergroup meetings would only be held on Thursdays.
Since then, we have attempted to resolve this matter.
We did not achieve it.
The intergroups today, Mr. President, must convene on an unsuitable date.
They almost never have private rooms and never have interpretation.

Today I speak not only as president of the Poverty and Human Rights Intergroup, but with the mandate of the majority of Intergroups in this Chamber, and therefore of the members of this Chamber who are part of those Intergroups.
I solemnly request that the Conference of Presidents reconsider and rescind the decision of February 14, 2008, and return to the previous status of freedom for intergroups.
And if you do not, I say gently as well that we will bring the matter to the Full Chamber of this House and it will be decided who within this House is sovereign, which is this Parliament.
Mr. President, International Day against Trafficking in Persons for the Purpose of Exploitation revealed data that should compel us to act with urgency.
More than 90% of prostitution practiced in Europe originates from blackmail and extortion.

And, in light of this data, we should ask ourselves if we are doing everything necessary to protect the dignity and integrity of thousands of women whose rights are also protected by the Fundamental Charter that we approved with the Treaty of Lisbon.
Because we are not speaking of the oldest profession in the world, but of the only form of slavery we have not managed to eradicate from old Europe.
Countries like Spain are making significant efforts in this regard, pursuing traffickers, raising public awareness, and facilitating reintegration plans for women who are victims.
But it is not enough.
Europe must be a single space for action and commitment.

The upcoming Treatment Directive presents an opportunity to address demand through education and to hinder the ease of access afforded, for example, in the offer to advertise across all types of media, as well as to increase bilateral cooperation with third States to combat this scourge from its origin.
We have an opportunity.
I urge this Parliament to remain at the forefront of citizens' rights.
Madam President, we all agree that the foreign service represents a historic opportunity for European construction.

But to achieve this, it is necessary to act with a broad vision, because this is not the time for internal struggles over resources that are transferred or withheld in the short term, nor for wars between the various European institutions.
What is now in order, conversely, is to establish a general vision of what the European Union ought to be in the world, that is, to do precisely the opposite of
And that is what has occurred in recent days, on the occasion of the awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize, where too many voices have been heard, coming from Europe, and not all of them courageous.
Notably, one of the exceptions is the President of this Parliament, Mr. Buzek, who is the author of a brilliant and worthy statement.

Mr. President, the regulation we are debating today is of vital importance for the future of a sector—the cutlery and related industries—which in my region, the land of Don Quixote, specifically in Albacete, represents, in addition to the survival of over eight thousand jobs, an element of identity and a forward-looking commitment to craftsmanship as a source of job creation.

It is the case that the Meidín knife sealing has long been championed by social groups such as Precu and contested by the Government of Castile-La Mancha with the unanimous support of its regional parliament.
A seal of origin that is not interventionism is a commitment to transparency in commercial rules and the fight against unfair competition.

It is to increase consumers’ decision-making capacity when choosing a product, ensuring they consider not only the final price but also the brand’s quality, the place of origin, or the social conditions in which it is produced.

And, above all, it will represent a new horizon of optimism for many people who are struggling, but who today look at us believing that we have not been indifferent when it comes to advocating for a fairer trade, yes, but also for adding value to those who, in addition to producing, do so with respect for social rights and the best conditions for European workers.
Therefore, I thank the speaker and Mr. Menéndez del Valle for their political support and their social awareness regarding this important issue for my region.
Mr. President, let me see if I can bring a little calm to this lively debate.
It is regrettable that certain countries and states comprising the European Union continue to be present at this G20 forum.
Despite this anomaly, which certainly weakens Europe’s image in the world, it would be beneficial if at least a global common position existed in that global forum.
And what, in my opinion, would that common position be?

In my humble opinion, I believe that, firstly, the adoption of a global agreement to address the consequences of the crisis cannot be delayed, and not merely a financial agreement. Secondly, Europe must maintain the euro as a reference currency or, if preferred, as an anchor for

To prevent market turbulence from sweeping us away and causing us to repeat the errors committed throughout the 20th century, the euro, thirdly, must serve as a herald of what Europe ought to represent in the world of democratic values and freedoms.
public.
In summary, it must be understood that in the global world, in this global game, loses the one who plays only national cards.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, I believe we are in the case of congratulating the rapporteur, Madam Meissner.
I believe that differing positions were identified, and she has achieved compromise solutions that allow us all to be together on an important matter.
Honorable members, the Transport Committee has decided that all seas should be protected in a similar manner, and to that end, it argues that failure to do so would result in unfair competition.

We accept the position of the majority in favor of a legal situation with uniform rules for the entire Union, but I will not fail to point out to your Lordships that it also represents a certain lack of equity.
It is evident that the Baltic Sea, the North Sea, and the English Channel are more polluted areas, and that controls of sulfur limit values should be more rigorous in those cases.
It is necessary to positively assess the measures concerning ports, as they affect solutions for reducing transport times and handling costs.
In any case, I will not tire of reiterating that at this point we have an outstanding matter.
If a decisive liberalization of ports is not undertaken, they will not be able to expand the central role they must play in the context of convenience.
Welcome too, Your Excellencies, the impetus for a strategy aimed at modifying the specific repercussions of climate change.
I believe this is a positive report, and it should be voted on.
But we cannot forget that it occurs within the context of a serious disaster, namely, that of the Gulf of Mexico.

And, in that respect, the Commission is urged to assess whether the framework for the review of the European Maritime Safety Agency Regulation strengthens the role that the Agency should play in prevention inspections and subsequent hydrocarbon spill cleanup tasks.
My personal assessment, Madam Commissioner, is that yes, and that these tasks should be reinforced with the mandate required for that purpose.
Mr. President, integrated maritime policy is a cross-sectoral, regional, and sectoral policy, which must include fisheries policy and aquaculture, and it should not be subordinated to other policies.

We must all respond to environmental and economic problems, both as a general society and within the fishing sector. New technologies, fishing techniques, species development, a maritime economy plan...

To foster more and better employment, quality supplies, international relations that avoid piracy, and promote the governance of our seas—seas that are without barriers and free from sustainability problems, as is the case with Iceland.
This would be working towards an integrated maritime policy; this would be working towards the environment and sustainability.
Madam President, recently the church of Our Lady of Sorrows was attacked in Baghdad and 58 people were murdered, the majority of them women and children, solely for being Christian.
Al Qaeda has proudly claimed responsibility for the feat.
It is not an isolated incident, but rather the culmination of persecution and attacks against Christians in countries with a majority Muslim population.
Expulsions in Morocco, threats in Turkey, attacks in India or Nigeria.
In January, six Christians were massacred at the door of a church in Cairo.
Cairo—How long will the complicit silence of Western democracies last?
Fortunately, President Buzek has made an official statement.
The High Representative, Mrs. Ashton’s, statement of condemnation has been limited to condemning a terrorist act.
Why isn’t the mobile phone cited? The condition of Christians, which is the unequivocal cause of the slaughter.
I have heard nothing from Mr. Zapatero, nor have I heard anything from President Erdoğan.
And Erdogan, what is the Alliance of Civilizations for?
I grieve our paternalism and our cowardice.

Inevitably, the lamented and misunderstood Oriana Fallaci comes to mind, who announced the arrival of Eurabia and was almost stoned for having the courage to denounce what is happening in complex Europe.
Also to the Honorable Commissioner. I share the desire of this Chamber.
I want the proposals from the Europeans to receive the support they deserve in Cancun.
In relation to this debate, it is important to underscore the role of cities in environmental preservation.
There is a pact among more than a thousand mayors in the European Union that demonstrates the recognition of the problem by these authorities, whose actions are decisive if we want to succeed.
Fine words are of no avail if we do not have the collaboration of city mayors.
For this, it is very important to disseminate information about emissions, as cities produce nearly 80% of greenhouse gases.
Currently, there is no such dissemination, nor, worse still, a common pattern for the measurement of these emissions themselves.
There is a non-profit organization called the CO2 Disclosure Project that already hosts information from thousands of companies and that, I believe, could also be utilized by municipalities.
Without their participation, without the participation of these municipalities and their mayors, the environmental action dissipates, the very smoke we seek to avoid.

Mr. President, some have said that the condemnation of Morocco is too lenient given the scale of human rights repression in the Western Sahara, in which Morocco is nothing more than an occupying country without sovereignty or legal title whatsoever.
But the important thing is the message that all of Europe and this Parliament can tolerate its violence no longer.
Yesterday, I spoke about the International Court of Justice in this very Parliament.

The international community, which regrettably failed to prevent the genocide in Rwanda, Yugoslavia, and Darfur, hopes to avoid, however, that of the Western Sahara and that we do not have to witness it before another court, also in The Hague, as I was saying, but this time for war crimes.
Mr. President, Commissioner, the Directive approved in 2009 was a success because it updates the regulatory framework governing toy safety.
It is a significant step in the right direction, because it points us towards the path to follow, but it is not enough.
We must always be vigilant and attentive to ensure that toys marketed do not endanger the safety and health of children.
All toys on the market must comply with current legislation.
We must review and improve the surveillance mechanisms to detect hazardous toys, whether due to substances considered toxic, fragrances, and other hazardous substances, such as HPAs.
It is necessary that the guidelines to follow be clearer regarding the warning concerning the minimum age and the dangers resulting from improper use.
The recommended age for toys needs to be based on studies of child behavior.
We must be able to adapt our regulations to scientific advancements supported by solid studies and be more rigorous in the surveillance of the market and the importation of toys.
It is necessary to work together and strengthen cooperation among the Member States and to rely on the joint work of customs authorities to control the route of imported toys.
Citizens are preparing to make their holiday purchases, and we must assure them that the products they buy meet all safety requirements.
In this debate, it has become clear that we all agree to support the objective of this report.
The various political groups have shown their support for this Directive, which offers greater protection to victims.
Therefore, I wonder what impediment exists to approving this instrument.
I repeat: What fears are there that something as necessary and straightforward as protecting victims equally throughout Europe should finally become a reality?
Hoping that this Parliament will overwhelmingly approve this report, I address the Council and the Commission, reminding them that we have
We have overcome legal obstacles in our negotiations, and I commend the Commission for recognizing our work, as we recognize the work it will do in the future.

Therefore, we must not exclude ourselves, but assist each other, approving this more concrete instrument today and tomorrow the broader package of measures to aid victims that the Commission will present, with which I pledge to collaborate.
Therefore, let us be brave and responsible today and help all those who have the right to live in a safer Europe.
Let us help everyone, I repeat, be they men, women, or children.
Let us help those who look to us today, expecting us to give them a better life, a life that restores their freedom, their security, and, above all, their dignity.

Madam President, the European People's Party Group will vote enthusiastically in favor of this report, and my first congratulations go to the rapporteurs, the Commission, and the Council for this agreement.
We coined, ladies and gentlemen, the term "democratic deficit" in the 1980s.
With him, we wanted to say that in the European Union, decisions were made solely by the Council of Ministers on proposals from the Commission, and this Parliament was consulted only for its opinion.
The battle of this Parliament since the 1980s, through the Treaty of Maastricht, of Amsterdam, of Nice, the Constitutional Treaty, and the Treaty of Lisbon, has been

to bridge that democratic deficit. And I believe that with the Treaty of Lisbon, with the new powers of the European Parliament, and with the participation of national parliaments, we have achieved that objective.
And we conclude today with this citizen legislative initiative, which, in the work of the Convention, was due to the good cooperation between national Parliaments and the European Parliament.

And I want to recall here the names of Jürgen Meyer, our German social democratic colleague, and Annan Lamassoure, who were the ones who brought that initiative to the penultimate Convention and ensured its approval.
Therefore, I believe we have completed the circle, Madam President.
I believe that today, when we vote on the initiative, we will have put, laid on the table, the death certificate of the concept of democratic decision-making.
It is now our turn, esteemed members, to act responsibly, and today we also have the opportunity to do so.
When voting on the Union’s budget, we will fulfill what is expected of us – a responsible Parliament and a co-decision-making Parliament.
I believe it is a good day for Europe, Ladies and Gentlemen.
Mr. President, in January 2012, 400 Spanish egg producers—approximately 30 percent of the total in my country—could disappear, resulting in a loss of production of 300 tons of eggs.

And the European Union could cease producing those 80 million eggs, those 2 million tons, and we would only find ourselves covered by imports from third countries, whose animal welfare standards are considerably lower than those of the European Union, if we do not act with considerable intelligence.
This Directive from 1999, which mandates an increase in the space provided in laying hen cages, requires us to act with intelligence and a forward-looking perspective, because, if not...

We will not only weaken European production and provide additional opportunities, commercial opportunities, to third-party countries, where space for birds is infinitely worse than the current situation we have in the European Union.

It is a Directive that demands enormous efforts from European producers. In Spain alone, we can see that the cost is elevated to approximately 600 million euros, but it is also important to remember that it has an economic impact extending to the ovoproduct industry and the food industry in general.

I therefore request the support of the Honourable Members for the Popular Group’s amendment to paragraph 2, where it is requested to seek a solution, at the very least, for responsible industrial operations that are proceeding with the transformation of their facilities and which will be nearing completion by January 2012.

We must support them in transforming those facilities and give them time to complete that process, thereby avoiding irreparable harm to the farms and preventing a sudden situation of scarcity in the community market, consequently increasing prices for consumers.
It is a matter of respecting the Directive, of giving an opportunity to the egg and ovoproducts industry, while also respecting animal welfare rights and the consumers’ right to a reasonable price.

Mr. President, I believe it is only right to thank the rapporteurs, especially Ms. Grossetête and Ms. Dagmar Romberen from my own Group, for the work they have done to move a regulation out of deadlock and make it useful, because that work has allowed the right to public health to be enshrined as a legal basis.

And to have a new orientation that allows us to lay the foundations to guarantee citizens the security and quality they choose at each moment, especially because it also allows for a clear regulation of the role of the States, both those of origin that must make the payment and those in which treatment is received.

But I believe we should not feel satisfied by that alone, but rather this must be the beginning of a much greater advancement that makes, as Mrs. Romperin said, this Directive a mere formality, because the level of equality achieved in all the States renders unnecessary each citizen’s displacement to each country.

And in that struggle, we must obtain a standard that better guarantees the rights of citizens in relation to the care they must receive, sensitivity, and security, than the mere right they already have to mobility between states.
Equality is what will drive Unity, and if not, we will be taking very small steps.

Madam President, the Spanish Socialist delegation has voted in favor, as has the rest of our group, but I would not leave here feeling entirely at peace without making clear my concern that this Directive includes
the issue of organ transplants, contrary to the view held by the Environment Committee as a result of the Council’s persistent insistence on including transplants in this Directive.

I trust that this inclusion will have the enormous effectiveness of the good legislation we approved in this very session, both with the Transplant Directive and the Action Plan, very recently and with near unanimous support.

I note that we will be vigilant to ensure that this inclusion does not diminish the excellent work done by such successful organizations as the Spanish National Transplant Organization and, of course, with the intention of saving twenty thousand lives that we had both in the Transplant Directive and in the Action Plan, which, I repeat, we approved here.
Therefore, I state clearly that we will continue to monitor compliance with this Directive in that regard.
Mr. President, today, moreover, is also European Day for Sexual Health.
Esteemed colleagues, the data are concerning. The World Health Organization estimates that over 300 million people unknowingly contract a sexually transmitted infection each year.

In Europe, as warned by the European Forum for Sexual Health, the increase in unwanted pregnancies among adolescents is concerning, due to an excessive lack of education and information among our young people.

Indeed, as the Commission points out, there are various and diverse inequalities in access to sexual health services in Europe, depending on the Member States and, within those states, depending on the income level of citizens.
To combat all of this, a European strategy is necessary.

Only five Member States have plans in this regard, but in all of them, it has been possible to reduce the number of unintended pregnancies, the transmission of sexually transmitted diseases, and also the number of abortions.

A common strategy that prioritizes prevention within the educational sphere, expands information policies, increases efforts in family planning, and facilitates accessibility to contraceptive methods.
A cross-cutting and ambitious strategy, free of taboos, to guarantee the rights of every citizen to sexual health in the highest conditions of safety and well-being.

Mr. President, at a time of intense social tensions, one cannot help but warmly welcome the significant social consensus agreement in Spain between the Government, the unions, and employers' organizations.
This agreement is exemplary for Europe, where such milestones have not been seen for some time.

It is also important to consider the reasoning of Cándido Méndez, one of the principal actors in that Spanish Pact, who attended the meeting of the Economic and Social Council in Brussels last Tuesday, February 8th.
Mr. Candido then insisted on the necessity of extending the concertation process to a European scale and on the need to have the voice and initiatives of trade unions in this our Europe.
Thus they should be.

Mr. President, setting aside the differences in matters of terrorism and immigration, I have observed that the European Union, regrettably, moves in response to emergency situations, such as a serious air accident.

an attack or a massive influx of immigrants like the one currently occurring in Lampedusa, where the exodus of Tunisian citizens toward the Italian coast could lead to a chronicle of a foretold death.

The journey of hope can end in a cursed journey and weigh upon our conscience, upon that of all those who witness these continuous, uncontrolled flows and do not say "enough" with sufficient authority.
When it happens, we will clutch our heads in dismay, but the next day we will forget.

European citizens have both the obligation and the right to know the truth: that the Mediterranean strategy is not working, that the common migration policy will remain a dream, while European countries do not commit to sufficient economic resources to ensure Frontex’s effectiveness.
Speaking costs nothing, but action is required.
Do they genuinely believe that Frontex, currently, can guarantee the security of European borders?
I believe not.

We hope that the citizens of Tunisia, Egypt, and other Maghreb countries do not decide to seek a better future en masse in Europe, but rather in their own countries, for which they have fought, and we must contribute to helping them achieve that.
Therefore, solidarity, responsibility, but, above all, truth, when discussing a common European migration policy, one that is more necessary than ever today.

Madam President, it has already been stated that the backbone of pension systems in Europe is and should remain the public system, because this is the only system that guarantees cohesion and the only one that, moreover, reduces the risks of poverty in our society.

It is nonetheless normative that in OECD countries, the highest indices of income equity among citizens are found in the area of pensions, or that, due to the crisis, private pensions lost as much as 20% of their value in 2008 alone, and that they continue, to this day, far from the solvency levels required.

All of this demonstrates that, at a time of unavoidable reforms, the sustainability of our pension system must be approached in a transversal manner, taking into account, among other factors, ambitious policies regarding birth rates or work-life balance.

ambitious policies regarding access to and retention in employment, or even immigration policies based on integration that also, from a demographic perspective, guarantee the sustainability of our pensions.
Finally, I regret that the text does not establish limits on the abuse of scholarship figures within companies, as these are generally excluded from all forms of social security contributions.

In my judgment, this is essential for an entire new generation of workers to whom, if they are being asked to contribute more to earn a dignified pension, it would also be necessary to make it less difficult for them to access decent employment.

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, we find ourselves at a pivotal moment in the construction of the future cohesion policy, which, following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, focuses not only on economic and social aspects, but also on the territorial dimension.
Territorial cohesion seeks harmonious development among territories to ensure that citizens can maximize the benefits of their unique territorial characteristics.
However, achieving this objective also requires advancing cooperation among regions of the Union facing similar challenges and issues.

This is the objective pursued by the European Union’s Strategy for the Atlantic region—a common perspective for addressing the shared challenges faced by the region’s States, including marine research, maritime surveillance, and environmental and economic challenges.

To achieve our objectives, it is necessary to adopt an integrated strategic approach aligned with the 2020 Strategy and the policies of the European Union for the period following 2013, particularly with regional policy and maritime policy.
Distinguished members, it is first necessary that this strategy be based on a renewed multilevel governance, founded on closer involvement of public authorities.
regional and local, Member States, the European Union, and stakeholders from the private sector and civil society organizations, including interregional organizations and networks.

It is a very significant day to discuss equality between men and women, because we celebrate International Women's Day, remembering those who, a hundred years ago, fought for labor and economic rights and for women's suffrage.
We have advanced considerably in these one hundred years, but much remains to be done, and true equality is still a dream, and the discrimination of women is a real fact.

I believe that each of us, men and women, can do much more to achieve the true emancipation of women, because there are many women in the world whose right to live is threatened, whose dignity is violated, and whose freedom is denied.
Allow me, on this International Women's Day, to express my support and my hope to all the women in the North African Revolution who are fighting for their democratic rights.
Because a woman cannot be worth half as much as a man, neither in Arab countries nor anywhere in the world.
Therefore, we are of equal value and deserve the same.
And I will continue fighting to achieve it, and as long as that equality does not exist, International Women’s Day will continue to exist.
Although there are many who do not want to see it, it is a reality that women earn half as much as men, and that domestic violence primarily affects women and children.
And I repeat, we must continue to denounce these facts in this Parliament, and of course, I promise that I will continue working.
Mr. President, I wish to express my agreement with the opinion of the deputies who have spoken here this morning and who insist on respect for Parliament and the Commission.
Therefore, my modest affirmative vote will depend on the willingness of the European Council to acknowledge the role of the aforementioned institutions.
Because the new mechanism we are discussing must be an important component of an economically-driven government, led by a European Union.
capable of ensuring coherence between the common economic policy, which must set clear, precise, and limited objectives, and this stability instrument.

That is to say, it must be avoided at all costs that this endeavor in which we are engaged ends up in the intergovernmental channel, which is a dead end or the channel of dominance by a few states, because all of this would frustrate the reform.
Dear colleagues, Europe is built stone by stone, and this is one of those that strengthens and balances this delicate edifice.
Essential points remain to be improved, therefore we must return the report to the Commission.
It does not end here, therefore, the interparliamentary work of this report.
The initial proposal was flawed.
That is how consumer associations were telling us, both at the national and European levels.
And, in particular, my esteem for the work of the Consumers’ Union of Asturias and its president, the indefatigable Dace Alonso.
We have managed to ensure the general principle of maximum harmonization of the former Article 4 was rejected.

It must be stated clearly that maximum harmonization when establishing the same protection in all Member States would entail a reduction in the protection afforded to many consumers, as there exists in various countries a greater tradition of protecting consumer rights.

I would like to emphasize, in any event, that it is essential to ensure that the list of abusive contractual clauses is not exhaustive, thereby allowing each Member State to increase the number of clauses it deems unacceptable and invalid in contracts with consumers.

Shift the burden of proof to the individual clauses, so that it is the merchants who must demonstrate that the clauses diverging from what is generally established have been negotiated individually, and that contractual clauses must be expressed in a clear and comprehensible manner.
We continue to oppose the establishment of maximum harmonization regarding abusive clauses.
The Eurobarometer indicates that 79% of retailers believe that full harmonization in this field will have little or no effect on their foreign activities.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, allow me, first of all, to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Schwab, and Ms. Gerhardt for the excellent work done.
and a general reflection.
It is not that protectionism is increasing, but rather that it is a matter of not cutting existing rights in some of the Member States.
Because if we want and pursue establishing a genuine internal market for relations between companies and consumers, we must
establish, simultaneously, a balance between the high level of protection of consumer rights and the defense of business competitiveness.
This balance requires agreeing to a minimum harmonization and allowing Member States to maintain or adopt additional regulations that improve consumer protection.
We cannot permit the adoption of a community regulation to mean the lack of protection for many consumers and users.
I welcome the improvement in negotiations within the European Parliament, but I would like to emphasize that rights already established should not be reduced.

Mr. President, many experts are telling us that the next crisis may be an energy crisis, and that, furthermore, either we are not doing the necessary work to avoid it or we are not doing it at the necessary speed to avoid it.
This coming Saturday, the World Forum for Nature issues a call for everyone to make a small gesture in the interest of sustainability.
Many citizens will turn off the lights for an hour, and many public administrations will follow suit.
But it is not enough.
Europe cannot continue to depend on energies that are not its own, that are distant, or on insecure energies.
We must help the States to build a new energy model in which renewable energies are the heart of the new
We must also support the raising of awareness regarding new consumption guidelines, because, without any doubt, renewables and efficiency are the keys to future sustainability.

Finally, I want to issue a call to all countries of the Union to join that call, that willingness of five of them, including Spain, to increase CO2 emission reductions to 30 percent, because in doing so, we would demonstrate that Europe, in addition to being a leader in freedom and rights, is also a leader in its commitment to the planet’s sustainability.
Madam President, the majority of the times I have spoken in this Parliament, I have done so to denounce violence against women, and once again, I am here to combat it.

I must say that I not only do not tire of this, but I consider it essential to continue speaking publicly about this violation of human rights, as there is no cause that can be defended without a platform, and this Parliament is the best.

It is the platform I have at my disposal to defend all those women who suffer daily abuse and who need us, legislators, to compel the States to punish aggressors according to the severity of the crime and also to help the victims.
