When it is estimated that one-quarter of European women have suffered gender-based violence at least once in their lives, and that children to an equal extent, I believe it is impossible not to demand greater commitment, as recognized by the Commission in its action plan.

I believe it is necessary to continue insisting time and again on leaving victims, as we already did in the European Order for the Protection of Victims, of which I was the rapporteur, and which I hope will become a reality as soon as possible.
This report has enjoyed broad consensus and support from the outset, which demonstrates that, when addressing domestic violence—which affects all members of the
Family, children, older adults, women, and men should not be a source of political opportunism, as it is to the honor of us all to advance the solution of this social scourge.
First, one must not remain silent, and second, one must begin to work, since, although we have been discussing gender-based violence for decades, we have not been able to reduce the number of deaths.

Something must be going wrong, and therefore it is time to abandon demagoguery and move from words to action, providing greater assistance and the necessary action to ensure women can live with dignity and security.
And security, so that all victims know that I will always be here to continue lending them my voice until, together, we manage to defeat this…
A terrible enemy that sadly ends the lives of so many innocents. I say enough, enough now, and I ask all of you to say it with me as well.
Mr. President, Commissioner, I concur with you that we must listen to citizens and regain trust in the European project.
Therefore, today could be a significant day for Europe and the construction of European society.

Because with the approval of these reports, we are not only moving forward toward the reactivation of the single market, a key element in the face of the current economic crisis, but we are also responding to the demands of citizens who call for advancing toward more Europe and strengthening social rights.
Europe must respond to new global challenges and ensure that the European economy becomes a highly competitive social market economy that fosters sustainable growth with more and better employment.

But this objective must be based on the insertion of a social clause into all legislation related to the internal market, placing citizens at the center of our attention and priority and strengthening their social rights.
Finally, I would like to request that the Commission submit these proposals as soon as possible.
Mr. President, blue tongue has been a constant threat to our livestock and, with it, to our public health as well.

A disease against which we fought through an activated vaccine, the use of which entails the creation of restricted zones for animal circulation, because the use of these vaccines can trigger unwanted viral circulation in uninfected animals.

For these reasons, the use of vaccination was limited to areas where animals had previously been found infected, creating a twofold detriment for livestock farmers: on the one hand, the disease itself, and on the other, the restrictions.

However, all these problems appear to be avoidable through the new inactivated vaccine, which, in addition to preventing the disruptions that can be caused in the domestic livestock market, allows for the development of new and, more importantly, broader prevention strategies in the fight against this disease.
For all of these reasons, it is of vital importance to this sector that we modify the Directive to permit its use, and that we do so as soon as possible.

Honorable members, compliance with what our Treaties stipulate, particularly concerning correspondence tables, cannot serve as an excuse for this regulation not to come into effect before summer, because with our delay, with your delay, we would only be harming the livestock farmers.

Mr. President, firstly, I would like to thank the Petitions Committee for the work it has done following the complaint presented by FEEPEX, which is the Spanish Organisation of Fruit and Vegetable Producers and Exporters, based on the report published in 2007 by OLAF, the European Union’s Anti-Fraud Office.

I believe the conclusions of that report are exceedingly clear and sufficiently justify the fact that the European Commission should have already begun work long ago to clarify the operation of the pricing system, at least with regard to the tomato sector.

However, the Commission has not only failed to intervene to resolve potential loopholes that the current access pricing regulation may give rise to, but has also negotiated a new agricultural agreement with Morocco without previously addressing the shortcomings of the existing import regime.

Honorable members, the time has come for the European Commission to take its responsibilities seriously and begin investigating where fraud occurs, and eventually request the recovery of unpaid customs duties.
I believe that a new agreement with Morocco should in no way be ratified without resolving the details that we have outlined.

Our objective is not to impede the signing of international agreements, but rather to ensure that said agreements do not seriously harm the interests of European productions and that the rules established in those agreements are respected.

Regarding the new agreement with Morocco, the European fruit and vegetable sector only requests guarantees that the effective implementation of the agreed-upon measures will occur, and this is only possible through the reform of the current import pricing regime.
Until we have a new entry price system, we cannot have a new agreement with Morocco.
We will not be able to ratify that agreement which the Commission has already finalized.

Furthermore, if control is the responsibility of the Member States, a significant economic effort should be required of them; however, it is also true that we have long been advocating for a European customs border system, following the example of the United States, to ensure that effective control.

Mr. President, Commissioner, addressing this report in Parliament has been complex, primarily because these measures require the approval of the World Trade Organization and the preliminary proposal sent by the Commission to Parliament differs from the one sent to Geneva.
We believe it is necessary to assist Pakistan, and we understand that exceptional trade preferences can be granted, provided they take into account the sensitivities of the
the European industry and, particularly, the textile sector, which in regions like the Valencian Community in Spain are severely affected by the crisis.

However, this report has allowed us to verify that measures that can be taken within the framework of international trade likely cannot be addressed with the urgency these acts require, and therefore, we should learn from this for the future.
Helping Pakistan, yes, but not with the Commission's original proposal, as it does not account for the effects on the European industry regarding the implementation timelines for sensitive products.
I would even delay the implementation of these measures because they do not align with the pending text expected to be approved by the WTO; we would be out of time.
Therefore, we consider it unacceptable to maintain this proposal and believe we will have to vote against it.
Mr. President, I would like to begin my remarks by congratulating everyone who has made reaching an agreement possible.

It is an agreement that we should all congratulate ourselves on, as it affects the daily lives of all citizens; however, with the constructive spirit that characterizes me, I would like to make a few observations.
First, I would like to draw attention to the importance of providing accurate, relevant information, but, above all, information that is comprehensible and consistent.
for consumers regarding the components of textile products. Comprehensive information will be of no use if citizens are subsequently unable to decipher it.
We have achieved a positive, necessary, but insufficient step. We should advance further and protect citizens who might become more vulnerable.
Distinguished members, it is essential to establish a European sizing labeling system based on body dimensions, because the first thing we encounter when purchasing an item of clothing is the size.
Therefore, we should be much more ambitious and seek the harmonization of sizes.
Mr. President, three observations regarding the situation created around the cucumbers.
I am of German descent and have a great fondness for that country, but it is evident that German authorities have acted in this case with haste and imprudence.

On the other hand, if we analyze European action, we observe that the actions undertaken by the Food Safety Authority and the Commission have been lackluster, muted, and imprecise; they have failed to coordinate or direct effectively.
Third, those harmed have the right to prompt economic compensation.
However, for the time being, I propose to this Parliament that we organize, in Brussels or here in Strasbourg, a large exhibition of European gastronomy based precisely on the cucumber.
One must reclaim lost honor—an expression pleasing to the German writer Heinrich Böll—one must reclaim the lost honor of cucumber producers.
Europe is the appropriate setting for it.
Mr. President, it is first and foremost obligatory to express my sincere sorrow for the twenty-three victims already deceased, twenty-two in Germany and one in Sweden.
And this crisis must be said to be the most palpable proof that the European Union must significantly improve its food alert system and its internal coordination.
The member states involved have demonstrated slowness, inefficiency, and inoperability; and, at this point, even after twenty-three deaths, we still do not know where the problem originates.

The European Commission must seriously reflect on the problems caused by its irresponsible actions or inaction during times of crisis such as the present, resulting in economic ruin and job destruction that formerly were

of unemployment, helplessness, and, of course, a health crisis with extremely high health risks for the population. Because while you, from the Commission, echoed irresponsible statements by regional authorities

very ill-informed and quite irresponsible [Germans], with names and surnames of Spanish farms, meanwhile, the population remained unknowingly exposed to the bacteria, believing they were avoiding it; citizens were more exposed than ever to eating something that could harm them.

The European Commission should today, at the Council of Agriculture being held in Luxembourg at two o'clock in the afternoon, propose to the ministers that part of the 2 million euros existing as unused carryovers from the common agricultural policy be utilized.
We will need those 2 million euros to repair as much damage as possible.

To that end, it is necessary to seek a legal foothold that allows for it, a legal foothold that has been found on other occasions, such as with mad cow disease or dioxins, and which should be found now.
Therefore, Commissioners, Ministers, today in Luxembourg you must be equal to your responsibility.

German authorities, furthermore, given the irresponsible accusations leveled, should support this economic solution, without a doubt and from the outset, and also contribute, with their own funds, to communication campaigns aimed at re-establishing consumer confidence lost in horticultural products.

Mr. President, Commissioner, nothing we do here or in the European Union will bring the dead back to life, and I hope that what is being done will prevent more deaths and halt the chain of suffering endured by those who did nothing to deserve it.

We do not know the causes, certainly, but we do know certain things that we must call by their name. There has been negligence in political actions, and there has been negligence on the part of the German federal government. It cannot act as if Hamburg were a state from another continent.

The arrogance displayed by Mrs. Merkel and her Minister of Health in their unusually frequent appeals to other states, had it been translated into diligence and effectiveness in coordinating, some of the things that have happened would not have occurred.

And that negligence has had criminal consequences for a State that has been the Spanish State and for its most important sector, agriculture, and has led to the ruin of families, small businesses, and has long discredited the economy.
I request that you go to the Council today and request total compensation for those affected, since we cannot demand life from the deceased.
and that the control systems be reviewed.
And that responsibility be demanded of Mrs. Merkel.
And that less arrogance and more diligence be requested of them.
And that she be held responsible for damages she has caused.
You cannot ignore that Hamburg is within your state.
He cannot ignore his responsibilities.
It cannot take refuge under a decentralized and federal state to inflict the damage it has caused.

A little more humility, a little more sound management, and a little less conservatism would have been beneficial in preventing this crisis from slipping through our hands, and ensuring that Spain and other farmers in the south would not have to endure its painful consequences.
Review the controls, review the alert systems, and demand accountability, because we are asking this of you, Commissioner, of the Council, and of the German State, here in Spain.
Mr. President, we are facing a public health problem, an epidemic, as the Commissioner has said, and in response, blame has been sought, rather than the cause.

The system has not functioned; we have twenty-two fatalities, 1 affected individual, and we do not know the cause three weeks later. And appealing to a principle of precaution without scientific basis—I repeat, without scientific basis—Spain is being blamed.
Honorable members of parliament, Spanish cucumbers were not contaminated.
They were contaminated, they were not contaminated. I repeat this because contrary versions have been heard here.
But so you can see the importance of what these words have sparked, 300 jobs could be affected, a loss of confidence.
An epidemic knows no borders.

I agree with you, Commissioner, it knows no borders; we are calling for responsibility for what has not been done, for what we must do immediately, because Germany currently has a risk issue, it has the highest number of affected individuals, but Spain is not to blame.
We demand compensation.
What is important and what unites us here today are the victims, because no one should feel as unprotected as European consumers do today.
And it is out of respect for the victims that we need clarity and accountability.

It is my responsibility to report to the German authorities that they unjustly and hastily accused Spanish cucumbers and, specifically, the cooperatives of Málaga and Almería, which were model farms and will not recover from those accusations.
Thousands of families without employment wonder why, why they need an answer, and above all, what their future will be—not only in Andalusia, but throughout agricultural Europe.

Therefore, and trusting that experts will swiftly find a solution, I demand that the Commission, when it speaks with the Council today, request immediate economic and moral measures for all producers, from Andalusia and from across Europe, who look to us with indignation, but with hope.
Mr. President, instead of prioritizing research and European collaboration, German authorities have defamed and harmed cucumber producers and others.
And still, no one in Germany has resigned nor offered reparations commensurate with the damage caused.
It is Germany that has a serious credibility problem.
The treatment of the southern countries by Mrs. Merkel regarding both agriculture and finance is intolerable.
Someone said that Merkel was a disciple of Adenauer and Kohl.
None of that lacks Moran credit.
Mr. President, it is no coincidence that Spain, Italy, Greece, Ireland, Portugal, or some other country share our reservations in readily accepting the so-called Eurovision.

The coincidence, criticism brings about the cause of our condition as peripheral countries, who, in the end, will be the ones paying this singular burden that will be collected by the States of the European Union that possess geographical centrality.
The reasoning that inspires the Eurovignette is fraught with significant contradictions, and the supporting discourse grows weaker with each passing day.

Although the rationality of internalizing external costs is accepted as a starting point, it ultimately fails to hold that, in order to alleviate congestion, only high-tonnage vehicles are penalized, leaving tourists outside, in the same manner that the old principle of "polluter pays" is applied with evident discrimination.

Furthermore, ladies and gentlemen, the Eurovignette, initially conceived as a source of infrastructure funding, will ultimately allocate only 15% to the financing of trans-European networks, and not in a mandatory manner.

but rather as a simple recommendation regarding the method and manner in which the Minister of Finance on duty will allocate the collected funds, so that he may deem most appropriate for the interests of his country, within the broad chapter of infrastructure.
The final outcome will be nothing more than yet another setback for the transportation of goods by road, which today is the only mode enabling the internal market.
This is the reality, ladies and gentlemen, a reality that is far more stark in a scenario of economic crisis.

In that sense, the competitiveness of European products in global markets cannot tolerate experiments that may contribute to further deteriorating the precarious situation of the European economy through the imposition of additional costs.

And, of course, the food crisis, which has been recklessly placed upon Spanish products, has produced an unjust penalty and substantial losses for those penalized by the Eurovignette—hauliers of goods and farmers of primary crops.
These are the reasons, ladies and gentlemen, for which the Spanish delegation of the European Party will vote against this draft Directive.

You will all understand, dear colleagues, that upon assuming the presidency of the session, I must express my sorrow and dismay at the passing of Jorge Semprún, which occurred a few hours ago at the age of 87.

We celebrate Jorge Sanprún, who was once a prisoner of the Buchenwald concentration and extermination camp, a fighter against the forces of Nazism in France, and against the Franco dictatorship in my country, Spain.
We also celebrate the remarkable, committed writer, a particular contributor to our program, The European Book of the Year, and we also celebrate the convinced Europeanist politician.

He mourned his death, both as a companion and as a friend, and I am going to ask President Buzek to convey a message of deep sorrow and solidarity to his family and to the Government of Spain, a sentiment I am sure we all share here.
the creation of a space for economic governance governed by the principles of federalism adapted to European construction.
We cannot continue to turn a blind eye.
It is inconsistent to have a single currency and simultaneously lack the fiscal and financial instruments that such currency demands.

Specifically, therefore, we need the issuance of European debt, a resounding no to competition between the debt issuances of the individual states, the creation of a genuine European public treasury, the
harmonization of fiscal policies that guarantee the equality of citizens, combat tax fraud, and help define a progressive European social policy based on effective public services.
These ideas, it will be said, are elementary.
But they must be repeated and repeated, because no one listens to them.
And precisely because of not listening, those dark times of which the poet Bertolt Brecht spoke are unfolding.

Mr. President, Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, the current economic and financial crisis we are experiencing highlights the need for regional policy as the best instrument for reducing development disparities between regions and states.
At the same time, we can reclaim the positive image of Europe that citizens have lately come to associate only with stringent austerity plans and social cuts.

The future cohesion policy, a pillar of solidarity, the European project, and social justice, must take the following priorities into account: first, to strengthen social cohesion and integrate the challenges posed by the 2020 Strategy; second, to consider the needs and characteristics

geographical characteristics of the regions, especially those most disadvantaged. Third, maintain the principle of gradualism in the allocation of funds, so that regions do not abandon the convergence objective, avoiding abrupt changes in the provision of aid, and fourth, foster a system
equitable.
Finally, ladies and gentlemen, authorities are implementing stringent austerity measures.
Therefore, the Union's support is necessary.
I hope the Council takes due note.

In defense of fundamental rights, I urge the responsible institutions to review the designation of San Sebastián as European Capital of Culture, because I believe it was chosen based on a political criterion, which constitutes discrimination against the other candidate cities.

The president of the Tribunal stated that I was selected to support the peace process and that, to my knowledge, there exists in Spain a terrorist organization called ETA which, to this day, has not abandoned arms and which, two months ago, secured the governance of, among other municipalities, San Sebastián for its political wing, Bild.

I do not believe that from Europe we should give such a powerful platform to those who do not condemn terrorist violence and will engage in propaganda to apportion blame between victims and perpetrators.
Where is the right to freedom and to dignity?
Of course, not in San Sebastián, where colleagues of ours, such as Mayor Oreja Iturgaiz, Salva, or myself, must be accompanied by security.
I believe in the culture of life, not in the culture of shooting.
Can true culture exist without freedom?
No and a thousand times no.
And when San Sebastián is a city free for all, may it present its candidacy once again, and in the meantime, may they learn the culture of respect for those who think differently.
Because tomorrow perhaps they will deserve it, but today, with Batazuna and its heirs in the institutions, they do not deserve it.
Mr. President, first of all, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for the fruitful collaboration they have provided in drafting it.
And the same I say with regard to the other deputy colleagues of the Commission of this Parliament.
Sixty years ago, the European Coal and Steel Community was established. There could be no better way to commemorate this event than to debate now on energy infrastructure in Europe.

Today, the European Union has clearly defined the objectives of its common internal market policy, the promotion of renewable energies as a means or instrument in the fight against climate change, security of supply, and diversification of its sources.

In the Treaty of Lisbon, a section dedicated to energy, Title 21, has been established, where the commitments I have just mentioned are formulated, as well as the promotion of interconnection between energy networks.

Consequently, the objective of the report we have prepared is oriented toward correcting energy infrastructures that, in the opinion of the European Commission, are outdated and poorly interconnected.

Thus, for example, we observe a spectacular increase in electricity generation from wind power in the North Sea and the Baltic Sea, alongside the immense potential of renewable energy in Southern Europe.
Europe and in North Africa, with the problems that derive from large-scale electricity storage, with the needs for recharging electric vehicles, among many other pressing issues.
All of this is impossible to confront today if we do not devise new networks and new connections, both within the European Union and with third countries.

It is therefore, in these coming years, a matter of advancing the determination of the necessary infrastructure, establishing the criteria that will allow for the selection of projects of European interest.

b) eliminating energy islands
c) ensuring the execution of these projects within reasonable timeframes and arbitrating formulas to resolve the contentious issue of the
authorization and licensing procedures in Member States, ensuring financing that attracts and stimulates private investment, without prejudice to the public support that may be necessary.
Energy efficiency and savings, as well as smart grids, are central ingredients in the new design incorporated into the report, because we have
It has been believed that by reducing energy demand, dependence on imports can be lessened, with the resulting effect on infrastructure needs.
A primary concern of this report from the outset has been the processing of licenses and authorizations intended to permit the execution of the necessary works.
These, currently, are eternalized.
And they are perpetuated by the opposition of populations to seeing towers or installations of another type grow in their vicinity.

To resolve this conflict, consideration has been given to providing early information to citizens and establishing a warning system in the event that the authorities of a State fail to address a request within a reasonable timeframe.
We face ambitious goals that require the participation of everyone.
In this regard, companies in the sector are essential, justly calling for a stable regulatory framework, the best way to ensure the financing of their efforts.
