We should not allow matters to remain as they are, therefore, we should take advantage of the negotiations during the next Multiannual Financial Framework to express our view.
respect and to force an agreement with the Council of Ministers and this Parliament to allow for the preservation of aid to the most vulnerable beyond that date.
Thanks to European aid, food banks have performed remarkable social work that should not be paralyzed by the selfishness of some governments.
That work has benefited 13 million people, and as a result, with minimal effort, we have managed to make the common agricultural policy somewhat more significant.

Mr. President, the regulation we are debating today is not perfect. It cannot, by itself, fix the problems of a sector with structural issues, and also due to the economic context we are experiencing, which includes circumstantial problems.
But this Regulation, though not perfect, is a step forward, resolute and in the right direction.

Because if, in recent times, we have all realized that there is no perfect market, it was very necessary to introduce into this board—where, moreover, we are playing with the food security of people—all possible regulatory and protective elements for our producers.

It was very necessary that we allow for the mandatory nature of contracts with a minimum and maximum term, at least as a defense mechanism, because, of course, our producers do not begin with the same negotiating strength when facing distributors, intermediaries, or collectors.
There are many things left to do.
We must improve safety nets and make them more agile and more effective.
We must prioritize further integrating the sector within the value chain, ensuring there is no quota distribution, particularly in certain areas, or promoting the quality policy.

But, without any doubt, with our positive vote and with everything that remains to be done, today many farmers can see this Parliament that has defended their labor rights, the most basic of all, which is the right to live with dignity from the income of their work.
Group B has accurately pointed out the disastrous consequences that the approval of this Agreement would entail.
Because this agreement, which expands quotas for certain fruits and vegetables, is utterly meaningless when the figures in this Agreement are not respected.

It is worth noting that the Spanish Federation of Fruit and Horticultural Producers and Exporters reported to the Committee on Petitions, of this Parliament itself, the massive entry of tomatoes through Perpignan at a price below that stipulated in the agreement.
Illegal situations such as the one described place the European farmer at a competitive disadvantage.
It should also be added that our farmers must adhere to rigorous quality, environmental, and social standards that our Moroccan partners do not always respect.
To conclude, I will point out the matter of the Sahara.
According to the United Nations Charter, the Sahara is an autonomous territory, and the exploitation of its resources should directly benefit the local population.
Furthermore, it constitutes an area over which the United Nations does not recognize the sovereignty of the Kingdom of Morocco.
From the European Union, it is necessary to ensure compliance with international law.

I am in favor of an agreement with Morocco, in favor of an agreement that establishes rigorous control mechanisms from the European Union regarding quotas and prices, an agreement that combats dumping, that does not exploit the Moroccan farmer, and, above all, that dignifies our European farmers.
This agreement is certainly not that.

This year, the European Parliament's Petitions Committee requested that the European Commission proceed with a modification of the pricing regime for the entry of fruits and vegetables into the Union, a regime that is facilitating the fraudulent entry of products from third countries, as stated by the Union's own anti-fraud agency, OLAF.
Primarily, they are Moroccan tomatoes.
The same request was echoed in a declaration signed last year by the governments of Spain, France, and Italy.

This, this fraud, is resolved by amending the Implementing Regulations of the Common Organisation of Markets in Agricultural Products, because aligning with the Customs Code does not resolve the problem, Commissioner.

For several years, within the Popular Party, I have advocated for the suspension of new concessions to Morocco until the European Union is equipped with the necessary instruments to guarantee the fulfillment of the current agreement.
The European Commission argues that it is the Member States who must guarantee control of imports.

However, what the Commission fails to mention is that the existing entry price system prevents national customs authorities from ensuring proper price traceability, hindering their ability to verify importer declarations for irregularities.

The Implementing Regulation of the Common Organisation of Markets in agricultural products is being modified, and this will resolve part of the problem, because otherwise, the legal loophole in European legislation prevents national authorities from doing their job correctly.
Once again, dear colleagues, the debate about a summit.
Many have been held, all announced with great fanfare, attempting to create an anticipation that diminishes daily.
They are ceasing to be credible because they are not contributing to resolving the crisis.
Peaks where the same agreements are repeatedly reaffirmed.

It should be known that, as long as progress is not made in political union and in strengthening this Parliament and the executive power of the European Commission, summits will be repeated, but the economic crisis will worsen.
In telegraphic fashion, two ideas: the first, the need to insist that responsible solidarity and the fulfillment of duties are the
materials with which Europe is built. Second, that the use of structural funds that remain unallocated be authorized immediately.
These amounts could comfortably address the unemployment figures of young European citizens.

Madam President, from the European Parliament, I wish to pay tribute today to all women, who, despite the significant progress we have made since March 1911, when women took to the streets to demand the right to vote and improved working conditions, I believe that gender equality remains a distant goal.
Today, women can work without having to ask anyone's permission, but in many cases they still earn less than men for similar work, which is unacceptable.
It is also necessary to remember the women in rural areas, whose labor is overlooked.
I believe another uncomfortable reality, but one that must continue to be denounced, is violence against women.

Already this year, there has been an excessive number of women murdered, not counting the serious threats from those who believe they have the right to inflict physical or psychological violence upon them.
It is time to say enough and to say it loud and clear.
From this Parliament, I reiterate my commitment to the European Protection Order for Victims and to the Victims’ Directive presented by the Commission, which, God willing, will be voted on next June.
Mr. President, we must also say, and I would like to reiterate, that motherhood remains an obstacle to women's advancement, and I believe this is a trend that should be altered.

Mr. President, I want to deliver a message of hope, and with many women, with the assistance of an increasing number of men, we must advance on the path of equality, of opportunities, rights, and also of duties.
We have come a long way, but there is much left to do.
I must admit that I do not absolutely and profoundly believe in quotas, but I have to tell you that something must be done, and I agree.
With many of my colleagues and, of course, with Mrs. Reding, for opening this debate and advancing this path so that women reclaim the place they deserve, and you can count on my assistance.

Mr. President, at a juncture of economic crisis and budget cuts that is impacting both public healthcare and in which, as in the case of the community where I live, research centers such as Príncipe Felipe, specializing in diabetes, are being deprived of funding, this Resolution is needed now more than ever; it is absolutely appropriate.

We need a common European strategy against diabetes, and we need a recommendation from the Council stating that Member States must increase research, even with stem cells, that they must coordinate their results to optimize them, and that they must establish programs promoting healthy eating and lifestyles.

In sum, we must prioritize the health of individuals above all else, and in this case, investigate, coordinate, and implement national programs coordinated by the Commission and demanding results regarding diabetes, to guarantee the quality of life of Europeans and safeguard their very lives.

If we dedicate more money to this, some will be slightly more involved in receiving payment, but it is certain that those who are currently experiencing problems will have a higher quality of life, and we will, as States, as Council, and as Commission, be fulfilling one of our obligations, which is to safeguard the health of our citizens.
Mr. President, of the many issues that this debate raises, I would like to highlight that of the emissions trading market, a market that was born with defects, certainly.
But today, the limitation of rights and the economic crisis have meant a drastic reduction in the price of carbon, that is to say, it is so low that polluting is cheap.
It is therefore urgent to reform the design of a policy on that market, because its deterioration threatens all green efforts, all of the European Union's green policy.
If emission rights are not valued, it incentivizes increased emissions. Polluting industries will not invest in new techniques, and worse yet
Funding for significant projects will be jeopardized, such as, for example, those relating to energy efficiency or carbon storage plants.
This is the risk.
It falls to us, to the Commission, and to the Parliament to bring it about.
Mr. President, few asylum seekers are permanently resettled in Europe.
My country, Spain, has barely begun with the experience.
The cases, however, are of urgent need.
The deputies verified this firsthand during a trip to Iraqi-Palestinian camps in Syria. Also, the news that immediately reached us from Tunisia.
Another more institutional aspect is the balance of power between the Parliament and the Council.
Our speaker, the valiant Ruiz Tavares, there are many good parliamentarians, but few with such tenacity as Ruiz.
Mr. Tavares has advocated for the European Parliament to retain the new powers obtained following the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon.
I cannot forget the sustained work carried out by UNHCR, without which success would also have been impossible.
UNHCR has made us all aware of the urgency of the report so that funds can be utilized as soon as possible, now that they are so needed.
And finally, many thanks, Commissioner, and I hope that we can also give you and your kind heart the satisfaction of advancing the asylum package next month.

The European social model, which we so proudly champion, is not solely founded on our pension, education, or healthcare systems, but also on a particular understanding of the balance between employer and employee within companies.

The labor reform approved by the Spanish Government without dialogue or consensus breaks with that social model and distances us from the objectives of the 2020 Strategy, both with regard to job creation and the quality of employment itself.
A labor reform, by itself, does not create employment; economic growth does.
What labor law does do is define under what conditions workers enter companies, under what conditions they remain in them, and under what conditions they leave them.

And with this reform, where 80% of workers will be left unprotected because they will not be subject to collective bargaining agreements, where they can be dismissed due to a decrease in company revenues.

Because they will be able to unilaterally modify their schedules, what remains clear is that workers will enter with greater precariousness, remain in the labor market with more fear, and leave it with less compensation.

Therefore, this reform, which undermines the European social model and which prioritizes the competitiveness of the Spanish economy solely in relation to workers' conditions, deserves a general strike, such as the one that must be convened tomorrow in Spain in defense of this social model.

Mr. President, Mr. Barroso, let me state at the outset that the Spanish delegation of the European People’s Party considers your proposals correct and supports both packages presented today, both the labor package and the solidarity aid to Greece, which is closely linked to the coherence of your approach.
It is undeniable, ladies and gentlemen, that we are living through difficult times, and events daily remind us that the crisis is still far from being resolved.
Attention has inevitably shifted back to Spain.
Unjustified alarms have been triggered in the markets, encouraged in part by statements, in my judgment, Mr. President, that were untimely.
One occurs within the framework of significant elections, in which both candidates cite my country as a dialectical element of confrontation.
Certainly, we do not appreciate any of the references.
On the other hand, some, in order to divert attention from their own problems, also treat us with a lack of political tact.
Today, here either, some have not been with Finnish—as Italians would say—and there has been some lack of political delicacy.
Honorable members, the state of the markets does not reflect the strength of Spain.
We are a solvent country with full capacity to meet our debts.
Spanish debt remains below the European Union average, and the Spanish Government is fully committed to meeting the deficit targets agreed upon with the European Union.
Never, Mr. Svoloda, has Mr. Rajoy said he could not meet the objectives set by the European Union.
He stated the exact opposite, that he is willing to fulfill each and every one of those objectives, and he reiterates this every day.

The Government of Spain, in the few months it has been at the helm of the Executive, has adopted and will continue to adopt ambitious measures to guarantee fiscal consolidation and lay the foundations for improvement in competitiveness, job creation, and growth.
The IMF’s projections, incidentally from yesterday, the IMF itself admits, predate the analysis of the decisions and measures taken by the Spanish Government currently.
Other measures adopted by the State General Budgets for 2012, which, in our judgment, will guarantee this year that the deficit target is met. The Organic Law on Budgetary Stability this month.
The reform of the financial sector will also undoubtedly contribute to financial institutions having to allocate over 50 million euros to developing countries.
In summary, Spain is meeting the objectives set by the Union and by the Commission, and what we are requesting is responsibility from everyone.

It is necessary that we all save ourselves together and Spain with all, without any doubt, and do not contribute in any way to criticisms from one side or the other. Either we are all the countries capable of being together and contributing to growth and the new economy, or, if not, it will be difficult, naturally, for us to move forward in the terms outlined by the Commission.
Now, shall we proceed? Do you want to make Mr. Rajoy, the Prime Minister, the protagonist?
That is acceptable to me; I would have no objection.
But Mr. Rajoy is not the protagonist of the crisis.

The protagonist of the crisis is the inheritance received by the Spanish socialist, communist, and green left, which has left the worst inheritance any government has ever left, when they received the best inheritance any government has ever had.
Mr. President, this morning I read in a major German newspaper the news that Spain and Argentina have a conflict related to an oil company.
This is precisely the wrong way to frame the issue.
The conflict is between Europe and Argentina, and beyond that, with that significant European value that is legal certainty and its respect in international commercial relations.

European institutions have excellent legal experts who can find the appropriate instruments within Community law, whether originating or derived, to neutralize the arbitrary actions of Argentine authorities.
I am a modest professor of Public Law and offer my services to them.
The credibility of the European Union before its citizens is currently at stake.

Mr. President, from the Committee on Agriculture, we share the ultimate objective of this Directive, which is to attempt to guide the composition of our energy mixes through fiscal imposition; however, we are faced with a very complex and difficult debate.

We are full of sharp edges in the economic, social, and environmental realms. It is important to maintain those balances that will allow us to advance further environmentally, yes, but that also do not harm us economically and that do not create greater social crises than those we are already experiencing.
This is the case of agriculture.

As everyone knows, energy costs are increasingly representing a very significant portion of the fixed costs of our agricultural operations, at a time when we are also engaged in a debate that combines crises in commodity markets with a prospect of aid requests and sanitary and environmental needs that reduce profit margins.
Therefore, we have primarily requested two things.

Firstly, the maintenance of zero-rate deductions on the energy component, now linked to the drafting and fulfillment of energy efficiency and savings strategies in rural areas, and the incorporation of
agriculture within sectors considered at risk of carbon leakage, in order to also access the deductions permitted within the CO2 emissions bracket.
That is to say, a policy that is more environmentally demanding, but which maintains those balances that make our rural environment viable at a time of change and uncertainty as well.
We are experiencing a significant controversy with austerity and growth as essential reference points.
If one hears the noise that is forming, it would seem that the idea of growth is a luminous invention of these days.
Nothing further from the truth.
In Europe, the Pact, precisely named the Stability and Growth Pact, has been in effect since 1997.

Therefore, a significant portion of the policies implemented by European institutions, such as those concerning regional cohesion and research, are policies aimed at growth and that pursue the development and well-being of citizens.

Therefore, and addressing the Commission and the members of this Parliament who have the greatest opportunity to be heard, we have no reservations whatsoever about engaging in that debate, a debate we can face with our heads held high.
This is my minority opinion among the unaffiliated.
Madam President, allow me, first of all, to thank all my colleagues and, above all, the shadow rapporteurs for their assistance in this report, which has made this report considerably stronger.

We all know that the twentieth anniversary of the launch of the single market is being celebrated, which must be the engine of economic activity and growth in Europe, key to overcoming the crisis and achieving the Europe 2020 objectives.

Over these twenty years, the construction of the internal market must be made compatible with its development alongside a broad framework for consumer protection, growth, and a right that generates dynamism.
and trust, transparency—a fundamental principle of democracy and good governance, as Commissioner Barnier referenced this afternoon—and cooperation between the Commission and the Parliament.
It is now time to develop the regulatory framework concerning the protection and training of consumers, and particularly vulnerable consumers.
We know that the diversity of vulnerability situations, both endogenous and exogenous, complicates the adoption of a global legislative instrument.
This compels us to address the issue of vulnerability from a cross-sectional analysis, taking into account the diverse needs, capabilities, and circumstances of consumers.
The Commission, being aware of current shortcomings, has focused its strategy on improving consumer information and education.
Being an ambitious proposal, it is not sufficient to protect vulnerable consumers, because their vulnerability stems precisely from their lack of assertiveness and understanding of the
information they receive, or the available options, or their lack of knowledge of existing claims and redress systems, particularly in the case of cross-border and online consumption.

For all these reasons, to address the deficiencies—that is, the problems—it is necessary to adopt a strategy of reinforcing vulnerable consumers and ensuring that both the Commission and Member States incorporate specific measures into their legislation to guarantee adequate protection.

that goes beyond mere information, especially in those areas where a higher level of complexity has been demonstrated and where the largest number of consumer complaints are registered—the financial sector—whose complexity implies that any consumer potentially could be vulnerable.

Therefore, the financial services industry is requested to redouble its efforts to provide understandable, truthful information, elaborating with clear explanations and using direct language regarding the nature of the products and services it offers. The food sector, in relation to advertising

Foods high in fats, salts, and sugars, and children and young people, who are the most susceptible to advertising for these foods. The transportation sector, which often continues to face challenges when vulnerable individuals travel, the energy sector, and telecommunications.

where a lack of transparency can, in some cases, create an additional difficulty for consumers, for example in the energy sector when determining the tariff that best suits their needs, or in access to justice, where consumers may encounter difficulties in accessing the mechanisms.
existing.
Therefore, the Commission and the Member States are requested, and allow me to issue a cautionary note to the Spanish Minister for Justice, Mr. Gallardón, so that rights are not rolled back.
and to proceed in a direction opposite to the march of these times of difficulty, to put intelligence and good governance in favor of an alternative dispute resolution in consumer matters.

Finally, let me emphasize that any one of us is susceptible to becoming a vulnerable consumer. Thank you very much, and I would like to express my gratitude to all those involved for the assistance provided in reinforcing this report.
Mr. President, Commissioner, the truth is that I have a feeling of desperation, almost of frustration, that I must share with someone else.
He will not allow me to do it with you this afternoon.

This is the third or fourth debate we’ve had in this Chamber recently regarding the situation of youth unemployment across Europe, and debate after debate, while youth unemployment rates are skyrocketing in some Member States, we are nearing the

of the active population rate, while many of them are already without any social coverage or unemployment benefits, while all of this is happening, while we transition from a situation that evolves from concerning to

From the unsustainable to the dramatically unsustainable. The Commission once again presents itself to this Parliament, to this Chamber, as if it were a political commentator, as if it were just another analyst, and not as the true Government of the Union, which is what it is, and moreover, what we need.

Commissioner, governing is about setting priorities; governing is about setting priorities, taking the initiative, and, moreover, with the objective of achieving some end, some goal, and, moreover, the Commission is not doing so.

Governing is not a simple restructuring of funds, nor even doing so and announcing it to polish one's image before public opinion, but rather elevating an ambitious, enduring, and rapid strategy to end youth unemployment.

Governing is not resigning oneself to a youth unemployment rate exceeding 20% and being satisfied with a pilot project of four million euros, which is ridiculous given the situation, given the magnitude of the problem we face.

To govern is not to yield to the pressures of the Board of Commissioners or of other member states of the Council who strive to convince us that from this financial crisis, this new wave of recession, we will only emerge by relinquishing wages, labor rights, or compensation; that only a future of precariousness awaits us as a generation.

Because if this were true, furthermore, Commissioner, that we only achieve competitiveness through precariousness and that we would only become more competitive by being even more precarious, then Zimbabwe would be the most competitive country, and it is not.
These are Sweden, Finland, and Denmark, which are precisely characterized by a model of exemplary relationships and also by a model of labor guarantees and rights.
Mr. President, employment is far more than a citizen's right; it is an instrument of connection to the system, an instrument of social integration.

Therefore, the more unemployment there is, the greater the political disaffection. And that is why, Commissioner, I will not accept your discussion of matters of jurisdiction as an excuse for doing nothing regarding youth unemployment.

Because, moreover, Commissioner, when it has been necessary to interpret the Treaties liberally to create, for example, the Financial Stability Fund, it has been done, and when the Treaties have had to be reformed to comply with or satisfy the delusions of some Member State on matters of austerity, we have also done so.
Therefore, what is it that I want to tell you?
There you have, for example, the Youth Employment Guarantee; it is unnecessary to explain it to you.

Advocate for increased funding, utilizing, if necessary, the European Social Fund as an instrument; design a co-financed and solidarity implementation mechanism that provides the most assistance to regions experiencing the highest unemployment rates; press for further modification of this policy, directing social support towards countries facing the greatest hardship; and remember that behind each statistic lies an individual experiencing hardship.
Then, will you agree that it’s not about whose responsibility it is, but rather for the benefit of all citizens, especially…
Madam President, Commissioner, I thank the INTA Committee for its work, as well as the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs.

Generally, we are dealing with a good G+ regulation—necessary, specifically in some actions concerning the control of import norms for textile products that could harm the production of the European Union.

However, we are concerned about the exclusion, beginning in 2014, of the System for Global Health (SPG) for certain countries classified as upper-middle income countries, such as those in Latin America.
What is the situation with middle-income countries that have undiversified exports?
diversified. Why not introduce a diversification criterion to export strategy?
Because this could generate two speeds; countries like Costa Rica, Cuba, and Ecuador would benefit from it, differentiating themselves from potentially developed countries like China and Brazil.

Therefore, I believe that we should support a period of transition and that amendments will be presented with this period of transition to adapt to this situation for these countries and to provide the possibility of opening negotiations and trade agreements with them so that they may benefit from it.

Mr. President, I already supported Ms. Nadelcheva’s report when I had the opportunity to accompany her on the Congo mission, along with other parliamentarians, and indeed, I have rarely seen communities with such a clear and demonstrable will to embrace and participate in democracy.
But a people, in order to believe in democracy, must also believe in their State and their Government, and that will not be possible solely through electoral support or external backing.
They also need a requirement to combat corruption and break the indecent paradox of living in poverty in one of the world’s richest countries in terms of resources.

It must be said and denounced that a portion of the violence they experience is imported or, at the very least, fostered by unscrupulous multinational corporations, which, from Europe or other continents or states, are capable of engaging in corruption without regard for fueling conflicts over those resources to gain favor with those who govern certain territories.

Therefore, Madam Ashton, although it may not be within your absolute remit, I do say that a greater requirement for traceability and transparency from multinational European companies and those from other continents that collaborate there would be as beneficial for the development of that people as the very assistance we can offer at an electoral and technical level.
Mr. President, to the speakers for the valuable work they have presented.

Honorable members, we are now debating package 2, after having approved package 6, following the agreement by nearly all Heads of State and of Government on two international treaties outside of the established order.

community, after numerous other European regulations have established additional community authorities for banking supervision, securities regulation, insurance oversight, and systemic economic risk management.
a proliferation of texts and more texts, of reports, of proposals addressing new economic valuation criteria, new procedures, new processes.
procedures. Shouldn’t we pause and apply what we already have approved?
Confronted with the instability afflicting the European continent, precisely the opposite—stability and legal certainty—is required.
We do not require a jumble of successive legal findings.
I don't know, dear colleagues, if I am dreaming.
The situation presented by the rescue is very concerning.
The full truth is not being told to Spanish citizens regarding the new debt, which, by guaranteeing private debt, the Spanish Government and State are assuming as public debt.
The Spanish Government has requested aid that it previously stated it did not want, presenting it absurdly as a triumph, something a colleague in this debate already cautioned.
There is no triumph but failure with Bank and others.

I insist, there is no further politically correct approach for Europe than the one sponsored by the French Government, behind which parliamentary ranks must coalesce, for we will not emerge from debt without a harmonious growth of all and the whole.

Supervision, as requested in both reports – definitively, all necessary supervision – but essential, simultaneous growth, also anti-speculative, and also as alluded to in some of the measures in both reports and other reports as well.
Please, clarity and transparency as well, balance, as my colleague Sánchez Presedo was saying earlier.
Madam President, since I entered this Parliament, I have not ceased to denounce female genital mutilation.
That silent and accepted crime suffered by millions of women and girls worldwide, seventy million, I repeat, seventy million.
An unbearable figure for anyone who pauses to study the terrible consequences of these practices, which are concealed under the guise of psychological, health, or religious reasons—all of them false.

The truth is that ablation, practiced preferentially on girls of fourteen and even one year old, can lead to death by hemorrhagic collapse and, at best, cause and bring about severe psychological sequelae due to the trauma.
From Europe, we must fight with all our strength to eradicate this violation of human rights, which undermines the right to equal opportunities and endangers health.
Esteemed members, this concerns abuse, cruelty, and torture against girls, and this degrading treatment also exists in Europe.
To that end, we must activate all the preventative mechanisms available to our legal system and I urge our judges to act to prevent female genital mutilation.
of girls in Europe, punishing those who perform them, that the law in Europe speaks with a single voice when combating mutilation on our soil.
Finally, I urge civil society and NGOs to actively engage in education and prevention campaigns.
There is still much road to travel, but many of us will not stop because we owe it to seventy million mutilated women.
Mr. President, Commissioner, I am fully aware that one of the reasons we approved the dairy package was precisely to adapt the sector towards a market without milk quotas in 2015.

However, it is also true that as this liberalization date approaches, uncertainty within the sector grows due to a lack of a clear exit strategy; similarly, the reasons why the sector demands prudence and reflection regarding the decisions we make increase.

Reasons, for example, such as the belief in maintaining vineyard plantation rights or sugar quotas, at least until 2020, reasons such as the uncertainty that exists in the sector regarding the real effects of the dairy package and concerning

We would have had time to conduct a serious evaluation of them and reasons as well, such as the uncertainty regarding the direction of the Common Agricultural Policy and, especially, its budget—that is, the portion of income that does not come from the markets and affects our producers.

Therefore, what is it that we are asking you, Commissioner, to convey to Mr. Cholos? That we not implement a piecemeal policy of dismantling our protection systems without a serious and rigorous analysis, because the effects on our producers are irreversible.

The deadline for the quota system will be postponed until 2015, until a date that provides security for the sector and opens an open and transparent debate on regulatory mechanisms, because markets remain more unjust and producers are increasingly vulnerable.
Mr. President, many members of this Parliament have heard the voice of the citizenry, the voice of the streets.
Commissioner, you have said that this is an all-or-nothing agreement.
We members of this Parliament also bear responsibility regarding a yes or a no.
And we say no because this agreement produces confusion, as is evident.
The rights of intellectual property nor the rights of internet users are clarified.
Are we concerned about intellectual property rights?
And that is essential.
Thus, ACTA is the solution.
No, there is no solution, because there are two matters to address—it is not a legal matter, but two political ones: a determination of the fight against counterfeiting and the
piracy and another new legislative framework for the digital environment, which we have repeatedly requested from the Socialist Group, we are requesting again.
It is your opportunity.
Do not turn your back on society, because tomorrow it will converge upon you and you will have no recourse.
If they are improved, it is sometimes necessary to accentuate the chaos.
The feeling of helplessness was of such magnitude that, inevitably, Europe had to react, and it has done so for the benefit of all, because the great winner of this past summit has been the euro.
And with this victory, hope has returned that Europe will overcome its paralysis, moving from reflection to action.
At this summit, Ladies and Gentlemen, it was as necessary to adopt short-term measures to guarantee financial stability as long-term measures to address the Union’s deficiencies.
In this instance, the immediate was essential to continue working towards what was important.
It was imperative to launch a message stating that the euro is a common, irrevocable, and irreversible project.

We welcome, ladies and gentlemen, decisions as important as empowering the European Stability Mechanism to directly recapitalize banks, which will allow us to break the vicious circle between bank debt and sovereign debt—a thesis consistently defended, by the way, by the current Spanish Government.
Furthermore, it will serve to intervene in markets in support of the public debt of countries that fulfill their commitments regarding public deficits and reforms.
Those were necessary decisions to ensure financial stability, which should be, in the short term, the European Union's top priority.
It is not this moment, ladies and gentlemen, for certain countries to resort to nationalist rhetoric and erect obstacles.
I have said it already; it is time to invest in Europe.
Spain, esteemed members, is adopting and implementing at record speed the most ambitious reform agenda of Spanish democracy, which includes a profound labor reform.
Furthermore, it is undertaking a financial reform based on complete transparency, and all of this demonstrates its commitment to fiscal consolidation and the fulfillment of deficit targets.

We also welcome the decision to launch a process for greater economic integration through four pillars: a banking union, a fiscal union, a common economic policy framework, and strengthening democracy.
Mr. President, the Community, and subsequently the European Union, has always been not only capable of resolving crises, but of emerging strengthened from them.
I am pleased that we have succeeded once again.
Dear colleagues, all our attention focused on banks, of which we hear again and again that they are the lifeblood of society.
It is likely that this image is accurate, but let us keep in mind that every body rests upon a vertebral column and joints.
Well, the backbone and joints of that social body we call Europe are precisely its transport networks and its energy infrastructures.
It is essential, as is being stated this afternoon here in the Hemicycle, to mobilize private funding and, where appropriate, public funding.

And, moreover, it is an opportunity to promote the issuance of private debt, guaranteed by European institutions, specifically earmarked for these purposes fairly and openly, and furthermore accessible to any investor.
Congratulations to the speakers for their work, and also to the Committee for its clear support of these projects.

Mr. President, esteemed Commissioner, Minister, in which I offer my greetings to the new Presidency, I am a veteran activist of the now-defunct Non-Aligned Movement, which your country led and which fervently desires the territorial integrity of Cyprus against military occupations.

Honorable members, the opportunity existed to pursue a broader reform of the Tribunal, perhaps, but the proposals of the Commission and my colleague rapporteur are very positive and should be supported with the unanimity they enjoyed in our Committee.
The agility and proper functioning of the Tribunal are fundamental, which I question with the new, currently delayed, patent jurisdiction.
Congratulations to the speaker; proceed with the reform of the Tribunal.

Mr. President, Commissioner Reding, my country has experienced too many setbacks since the People's Party came to power, repeated and continuous attempts to roll back established rights, such as silencing dissent, among others, consumer organizations.
The threat to Facua, infringing, among others, articles 16 and 17 of the Spanish Constitution by the Ministry of Ms. Mato, is a dangerous attack.

Not only to freedom of expression and opinion, but also to the right to a high level of consumer protection, fundamental principles of democracy and enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.
I therefore request that the Government of Mr. Rajoy rectify the transgression of illegalizing Facua, and I make an appeal to the Commission to ensure the protection of the
to defend the rights of Spanish consumers and to act against the reduction of rights and the functions of consumer associations that the current Spanish Government intends to impose.
Madam President, Commissioner, first and foremost, I want to highlight the significant work of Ms. McAvan, the rapporteur, and also of the other shadow rapporteurs in reaching this agreement.
This initial review of the agreement was very important, as it brought into effect the regulation we had approved in 2010, and it was necessary to revise it.
Not because it was poor legislation—the legislation was very good—but, as has been said, the recent events, known to all, demonstrated that there was a certain
A gap that needed to be corrected to prevent recurrence, and specific points of medication surveillance and security after commercialization needed to be reinforced.

Therefore, from now on, as has been stated, the holders of a marketing authorization for a medicinal product who do not renew, withdraw, request the withdrawal of, or suspend the authorization will have
It is the obligation to declare the real reasons and the motives that have led to this withdrawal or the suspension of a medicinal product’s authorization.
This is a significant achievement in the interest of transparency and will prevent the holder of a marketing authorization from attempting to conceal the true reasons for their decision.
Furthermore, should any of these actions be carried out in a third country, all affected countries and all Member States where this medication is marketed must be informed.
Everything will improve transparency and security, without unduly burdening the European Medicines Agency and the national agencies.

The second significant modification achieved is that all authorized products subject to a post-authorization safety study will be automatically included in a list of products subject to this monitoring.
Finally, we must not forget that pharmacovigilance plays a fundamental role, and therefore, this Plenary Session should approve this proposal.
Mr. President, the agreement reached by the Parliament and the Council reflects what the involved Member States unanimously approved at the IMO.
These seas exhibit a concerning state regarding acidification.
Furthermore, its regenerative capacity is very limited.
The mandated fuels are going to be more expensive, and therefore economic assistance for businesses is anticipated, which is very reasonable.
But some colleagues have attempted to have the requirements for new fuels applied to all seas of the European Union as well.

We would encounter the paradox of a European Union country’s environmental problem being resolved by creating a first-order economic problem in the Mediterranean, a region that does not have that problem but does have other environmental issues for which costs are not intended to be imposed on the rest of the countries.
The Treaty is very clear.
Sensitive areas must be protected.
But not all zones are equally sensitive.

Mr. President, I want to once again thank everyone who has made this Directive a reality, the Secretariat, the Commissioner, the rapporteur, everyone I may have overlooked, and all my colleagues who have stood with us.
I want to say to the victims, to all of them, absolutely all of them, without distinctions, that for us they and their families have faces, have names, are real, and precisely, in their name.

Today, we will work to ensure that this Directive does not merely remain on paper, but, with the commitment and assistance of Commissioner Reding, which I absolutely do not doubt, achieves a rapid and effective implementation—which is what we all expect and all
citizen.

I believe there are different groups of victims who would have wanted and still want a dedicated Directive, but I will tell you that the Directive we will vote on tomorrow does not forget any victim and, therefore, does not forget them either.
And I am certain that this is a first and important step, which will be followed by many other steps that will open those doors of justice that have been closed for too long for the victims.
When asked in my country what I do in Europe, I will be able to say with great pride that I am legislating in favor of victims.
And that work, personally, deeply honors me and gives me great strength to continue working.

I am confident that with the support and commitment not only of those of us working here in Europe, but also in our countries, we will, together and with the support of the Honourable Member, bring the victims out of that unjust oblivion.

Mr. President, the colleague Turmes has done admirable work because advancing a regulation like this required the courage of this rapporteur, who has successfully neutralized the many and skillfully arranged obstacles.
It has been worthwhile because energy efficiency and its savings are requirements of any energy policy worthy of the name.

We should commend significant measures such as the requirement for the renovation of public buildings, the imposition of an accumulated energy savings percentage on energy companies, as well as mandatory audits for large private enterprises.
Now, however, to what end will the work of Turmes and the other rapporteurs serve if it is not accompanied by decisive action from the Member States?
An action that, in turn, must be accompanied by a firm commitment to these objectives on the part of the regions, the municipalities, and European citizens.
I wish to highlight the involvement of these latter.
At present, what is observed is a great deal of frivolity among both authorities and citizens.
Don't we see, dear colleagues, in the harsh European winter people seated on heated sidewalk terraces?
Friend Turness, we must not spare any effort to save energy.
We must commend the speaker, Ms. Aira García, for the work she has done, and congratulate ourselves on the agreement reached between the Parliament and the Council of Ministers.
It is regrettable that the Council cannot join us tonight.
Mr. President, the new quality scheme for agricultural products represents a simplification of the system and an acceleration of existing authorization procedures, and that is good news.

Furthermore, it is a significant achievement that the obligation to use the Community logo has been included for protected geographical indications and designations of origin, as this facilitates the enhanced visibility of European products.
It also seems to me that it is noteworthy to reinforce the provisions for the protection of quality appeals in bilateral agreements with third countries and to establish a legal basis for
Defending the European Union’s logo in those third countries, because I genuinely believe that the protection of European products in third countries should be an unwavering objective.

It is regrettable that during the negotiation this package ended up somewhat depleted, and a pity, I say again, that the Council is not here to hear it, because the original quality package that it proposed

The Commission has somewhat been forgotten regarding commercial standards and the management of supply by quality denominations of origin, detached from the agreement and, as I say, leaving it a little hollow.
I believe it is regrettable that the Council has demonstrated such a rigid stance in these two matters, refusing to hear the positions of Parliament, which are reasonable.
The management of supply by appellations of origin should have been defended and will be defended, certainly, within the WTO.

Mr. President, the trade agreement with Central America, Colombia, and Peru is an important agreement, and the safeguard clause—with the amendments we have presented—aims to be straightforward, efficient, and to provide guarantees.

We have submitted amendments to protect European production, in accordance with the Treaties, and we are establishing security mechanisms for both European production and production there, in the countries where the Agreement is established.
Protection of ultraperipheral zones is necessary, because they do not have diversified crops, due to economic factors, because it affects a large number.
jobs, more than 10 direct and 35 indirect jobs in Spain, in a population severely affected by unemployment and its particular circumstances.
For example, the Canary banana possesses a significant specificity in agriculture, culture, and gastronomy.

But it is also necessary there, where we will establish the agreement, in Central America, Colombia, and Peru, because trade is fundamental to development, and development means labor rights, sustainability, and benefits for the producer.

Mr. President, the speaker’s work is very good, but I want to take this opportunity to say here, within this framework, that our prose is very confusing, as anyone can observe who approaches European legislation.
Let us disregard what Puffendorf previously taught, that general laws should be few and their meaning must be correctly understood.
For them, those who promulgate it must employ all possible clarity.
And Montesquieu consistently insisted that legal language must be precise and concise.
That is to say, we must avoid esoteric jargon, replete with neologisms and unwarranted loanwords, because it generates a pernicious web where traps reside and arbitrariness takes root.
We address very complex matters in this Parliament, but it is our obligation to convey them to the citizenry in a comprehensible and accessible manner.
It is common for even legal professionals themselves—judges, lawyers—to feel despair when confronted with our texts.
Good prose, dear colleagues, is the courtesy of the legislator and a way of demonstrating his respect for the citizen.
Mr. Deputy, I have just spent my time—the little I had—insulting and denigrating from the utmost ignorance.
Ignorance. Do you know the Spanish Constitution?

What the Vice President, Mr. Vidal Cuadrás, has stated is nothing more nor less than the application of what is stipulated in the Spanish Constitution. Everything else consists of singular, personal opinions that are absolutely irrelevant and which I can respect, but I disregard.

Mr. President, esteemed members, there exists an old principle that has passed from the legal sphere to the political one, and it is *pacta sunt servanda*, that is to say, agreements are to be fulfilled.
By this, I refer to the significant measures adopted by the European Council in June to resolve the crisis affecting us.

Since the adoption of these agreements, market pressure has eased, and these decisions have been positively received—decisions that may break the vicious cycle between banks and sovereign debt, as well as the plans to move toward a genuine economic and monetary union and the commitment to defend the euro irrevocably.
The European Council, held last week, contains, Ladies and Gentlemen, undeniable positive aspects. The conclusions regarding progress towards banking union are satisfactory.
It is also positive that the A27 Agreement has been reached to launch the banking supervisor. Finally, it is appropriate to entrust the launch to the economy ministers of the Eurozone.
But he will be permitted to make a critical assessment of the biased interpretations that, in a unilateral manner, have been made of it.

It is not admissible, ladies and gentlemen, to make particular interpretations that may distort the mandate entrusted to the ministers of economy, nor do we applaud the recounting of matters as agreements when they were not even discussed.
It is urgent to move towards a single supervisory mechanism, which must cover all financial entities.
It is also necessary to establish a common deposit guarantee scheme and a crisis resolution mechanism.
The survival of the euro is linked to the urgent creation of an effective banking union.
Madam President, esteemed members, Commissioner, the advantages of the internal market are undeniable: increased competition, an expanded offering of products and services.
services, the creation of new jobs, more accessible prices for consumers, and greater protection—still insufficient, and we cannot fall into complacency.
However, cultural, linguistic, protectionist, and bureaucratic barriers prevent citizens and businesses from fully capitalizing on the advantages of the single market.
Half a year ago, we celebrated the presentation of the twelve priorities to stimulate growth and strengthen citizens’ confidence in the market.
Regrettably, an agreement has not yet been reached on the majority of proposals, as acknowledged by the Commission in last week’s communication.

Distinguished Members, Commissioner, the urgency of the crisis compels us to be ambitious, to go far beyond and to reach agreements as soon as possible to boost growth, employment, and the confidence of citizens and businesses in the single market.
Mr. President, I too would like to congratulate the speaker and the rest of my colleagues who have worked on this reform so appropriately.

The financial crisis has intensified due to the existence of complex and unusual tradable instruments that are linked to derivative instruments and to transactions outside of official markets, all with the aim of achieving high returns rapidly.
It is necessary to bring financial operations to a transparent market to guarantee the proper price formation and the competitiveness of negotiable products.
But, above all, it is essential that the information provided be comprehensible to investors, who must have full knowledge to freely consent to the risks they assume.
Transparency is of no use as a bright flash of light if the entanglement in the configuration of negotiable products blinds the understanding of citizens.

Mr. President, I appreciate the report by Mrs. Thyssen, because I believe that anything that strengthens the role and authority of this Parliament in political debate is moving in the right direction.
Far too often, we hear the accusation leveled against European institutions regarding their limited democratic quality.
This is a statement made casually, which is not the occasion for entering into this debate.

Yes, to emphasize that this Parliament possesses the same legitimacy as any national Parliament and is, indeed, likely to be governed by more transparent rules than some, and furthermore, allows its members greater freedom.
Therefore, all economic measures must pass the filter that this Parliament represents before their final approval and subsequently, upon examining their execution and results.
the group of experts designated to verify in the United States compliance with the conditions imposed by the Community authorities and the representatives of the Member States
The mechanisms of stability must appear in this Chamber so that we, the deputies, can have access to comprehensive information and firsthand information.
Mr. President, 5.3% of the active population works in the automotive sector.
The figures speak for themselves.
The decline in sales in the European market, combined with corporate strategy, means that, generally speaking, outsourcing and restructuring of companies
There is an overcapacity crisis currently affecting ten assembly plants and potentially one hundred thousand workers.

Unfortunately, there are few cases of restructuring with a long-term vision; a short-term perspective generally prevails, in which the primary element is gaining competitiveness through labor adjustments.

I must say that on the very day Ford announced the suspension of the GEN plant, the Ford company in Valencia was also informed, in the same corporate communication, that its production would be moved to Germany.

Therefore, for this reason, we believe it to be a general problem of Europe; we believe that the creation of a legal framework at the European level is essential to anticipate changes and underscore the importance of social dialogue.
Social dialogue is fundamental.
Mr. President, today we are debating four reports that represent a revitalization of our common security and defense policy.
It is a clear sign of the conviction that our security and defense have a distinct European dimension, in contrast to the minority and Eurosceptic sectors that also prevail in this Chamber.
Mr. Danjan's report, for which I wish to express my gratitude for its consensus-seeking approach during its preparation, contains significant contributions from the Socialist Group.
among others, references to effective multilateralism, the principle of the responsibility to protect, or the concept of human security.
We would like to see these aspects included in a possible revision of the European defense strategy.
We have also noted that a strong common policy on security and defense is also in the interest of our transatlantic alliance.
I must highlight another of the challenges that is acquiring significant dimensions for our global security.
It is the report on cybersecurity and cyber defense, a report that we also debated today and whose suggestions we hope will be included in the new European cybersecurity strategy.
Within a context of severe economic and financial crisis, in which Member States are being compelled to reduce their defense budgets, it is precisely when such European projects are most needed.
Therefore, it is more important than ever to strengthen the role of the European Defence Agency, which is being strongly challenged today.
I conclude by affirming that we can relaunch European security and defense and do so with the project of former President von der Leyen for the December 2013 Council.
Many thanks to the four speakers.
Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen, once again the defense of the general interests championed by the Commission and the Parliament collides with national egoisms entrenched in the Council.
Having previously accepted the legitimacy of both positions, achieving a balance is now unavoidable.
The relevance of the upcoming financial framework is undeniable.
The Spanish delegation of the EPP and I, on its behalf, reiterate that the Presidency’s proposal is, in our judgment, unacceptable.
A reduction of 75 million euros on the already inevitably meager proposal from the European Commission is sterile and futile.
And it's not just that; the new cuts directly to agricultural and cohesion policies represent crossing the red line that Spain established from the beginning of the negotiations.
Distinguished members, the time for debating a purported dichotomy between austerity and growth has passed.
Some of us are making proven efforts and sacrifices to correct the deficit.
But Spain, like so many other countries, needs to grow, increase economic activity, and create jobs.
With this budget, we achieve nothing; rather, it undermines the waterline.
Honorable members, it is not possible to achieve more Europe with far fewer resources, and especially if what we have is distributed unjustly.

If that is the case, Spain will oppose a financial framework for the European Union that, quite simply, entails the disappearance of possibilities for growth and, above all, any trace of solidarity; and this is precisely the direction the European Council is taking.
Fortunately, this is not the path indicated by the Commission, to whom we owe thanks for their efforts in pointing out a different route.

And at this point, in the need for the Union, in the need for shared efforts, I want to thank Mr. Barroso for, the other day in Cádiz, making a forceful statement interpreting the Treaties regarding a purported secessionist within the Union.

He made it clear, unequivocally, as Guarantor of the Treaties, that if a part of a Member State separates as an independent State, it shall be considered a third country and, therefore, the declarations and effects of the Treaty itself shall not affect it in any respect.

I hope, Mr. Vice President, in the absence of the President, that this may be recorded and that this certain and consistent doctrine of the Commission may continue to remain alive for the guarantee of all.
